§ 10.01 DESIGNATION; CITATION; REFERENCES.
   (A)   All ordinances of a permanent and general nature of the town as
revised, recodified, rearranged, renumbered and consolidated into component
codes, titles, chapters, subchapters and sections shall be known and designated
as the codified ordinances of the Town of Oceana, West Virginia, for which
designation “codified ordinances” may be substituted. Code, title, chapter,
subchapter and section headings do not constitute any part of the law as
contained in the codified ordinances.
   (B)   All references to codes, titles, chapters, subchapters and sections
are to such components of the codified ordinances unless otherwise specified.
Any component code may be referred to and cited by its name, such as the
“traffic code”. Sections may be referred to and cited by the designation “§”
followed by the number, such as “§ 101.01”.
§ 10.02 GENERAL DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this code of ordinances, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   COUNCIL. The legislative authority of the town.
   COUNTY. Wyoming County, West Virginia.
   LAND or LANDS and REAL ESTATE or REAL PROPERTY. Include lands, tenements and
hereditaments, and all rights thereto and interests therein except chattel
interests.
   LAWS OF THE STATE. Includes the Constitution of the state and the
Constitution of the United States, and treaties and laws made in pursuance
thereof.
(W. Va. Code 2-2-10)
   MUNICIPALITY or TOWN. The Town of Oceana, West Virginia.
   OFFENSE. Includes every act or omission for which a fine, forfeiture or
punishment is imposed by law.
(W. Va. Code 2-2-10)
   OWNER. When applied to property, includes any part owner, joint owner or
tenant in common of the whole or part of such property.
   PERSON or WHOEVER. Includes corporations, societies, associations and
partnerships, and other similar legal business organizations.
   PERSONAL ESTATE or PERSONAL PROPERTY. Includes goods, chattels, real and
personal, money, credits, investments and the evidences thereof.
(W. Va. Code 2-2-10)
   PRECEDING, SUCCEEDING or FOLLOWING. When used in reference to any section or
sections of a chapter or section means next preceding, next succeeding or next
following that in which such reference is made.
(W. Va. Code 2-2-10)
   PREMISES. As applied to property, includes land and building.
   PROPERTY or ESTATE. Embraces both real and personal estate.
(W. Va. Code 2-2-10)
   PUBLIC PLACE. Includes any street, sidewalk, park, cemetery, school yard,
body of water or watercourse, public conveyance or any other place for the sale
of merchandise, public accommodation or amusement.
   REGISTERED MAIL. Includes certified mail.
   STATE. The State of West Virginia or any department, division, commission,
board, educational or other institution of the state.
   STREET. Includes alleys, avenues, boulevards, lanes, roads, highways,
viaducts and all other public thoroughfares within the town.
   TENANT or OCCUPANT. As applied to premises, includes any person holding a
written or oral lease, or who actually occupies the whole or any part of such
premises alone or with others.
   WRITTEN or IN WRITING. Includes any representation of words, letters or
figures, whether by printing, engraving, writing or otherwise. But when the
signature of any person is required, it must be in his or her own proper
handwriting, or his or her mark, attested, proved or acknowledged.
(W. Va. Code 2-2-10)
§ 10.03 RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.
   (A)   General rule. All words and phrases shall be construed and understood
according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words
and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate
meaning in the law shall be construed and understood according to such peculiar
and appropriate meaning.
   (B)   Gender and plural. A word importing the singular number only may be
applied to several persons or things, as well as to one person or thing; a word
importing the plural number only may be applied to one person or thing as well
as to several; and a word importing the masculine gender only may be applied to
females as well as males.
(W. Va. Code 2-2-10)
   (C)   Computation of time. The time within which an act is to be done shall
be computed by excluding the first day and including the last, or if the last
be a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday it shall also be excluded.
(W. Va. Code 2-2-3)
   (D)   Joint authority. Words purporting to give a joint authority to three
or more persons confer such authority upon a majority of them, and not upon any
less number.
(W. Va. Code 2-2-10)
   (E)   Exceptions. The rules of construction shall not apply to any law which
contains any express provision excluding such construction, or when the subject
matter or context of such law may be repugnant thereto.
§ 10.04 REPEAL OF REPEALING ACT; EFFECT OF REPEAL.
   (A)   When a law which has repealed another is itself repealed, the former
law shall not be revived without express words for that purpose.
(W. Va. Code 2-2-9)
   (B)   The repeal of a law, or its expiration by virtue of any provision
contained therein, shall not affect any offense committed, or penalty or
punishment incurred, before the repeal took effect or the law expired, save
only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform as far as practicable to the
laws in force at the time such proceedings take place, unless otherwise
specially provided; and that if any penalty or punishment be mitigated by the
new law, such new law may, with the consent of the part affected thereby, be
applied to any judgment pronounced after it has taken effect.
(W. Va. Code 2-2-8)
   (C)   The repeal by any provision of the codified ordinances of an ordinance
validating previous acts, contracts or transactions shall not affect the
validity of such acts, contracts or transactions, but the same shall remain as
valid as if there had been no such repeal, but no further.
(W. Va. Code 2-2-11)
§ 10.05 CONSTRUCTION OF SECTION HEADINGS.
   (A)   When reference is made to any section or group of sections of the
codified ordinances, such reference shall extend to and include any amendment
of or supplement to the section or group of sections so referred to or any
section or sections hereafter enacted in lieu thereof; and unless otherwise
provided, whenever a reference to a section or group of sections is made in any
amendment or supplement to any section of the codified ordinances hereafter
enacted, such reference shall be deemed to refer to the section or sections as
the same shall then stand or as thereafter amended.
   (B)   Whenever in a penalty section reference is made to a violation of a
section or an inclusive group of sections, such reference shall be construed to
mean a violation of any provision of the section or sections included in such
reference.
   (C)   References in the codified ordinances to action taken or authorized
under designated sections of the codified ordinances include, in every case,
action taken or authorized under the applicable legislative provision which is
superseded by the codified ordinances.
   (D)   If a section refers to a series of numbers or letters, the first and
the last numbers or letters in the series are deemed to be included.
§ 10.06 ACTS BY AGENT OR DEPUTY.
   When a section requires that an act be done by an officer or person, it
shall be sufficient if it be done by his or her agent or deputy, unless it be
such as cannot lawfully be done by deputation.
(W. Va. Code 2-2-5)
§ 10.07 CONFLICTING PROVISIONS.
   If the provisions of different codes, articles or sections of the codified
ordinances conflict with or contravene each other, the provisions bearing the
latest passage date shall prevail. If the conflicting provisions bear the same
passage date, the conflict shall be construed so as to be consistent with the
meaning or legal effect of the questions of the subject matter taken as a
whole.
§ 10.08 SEPARABILITY.
   Each section of the codified ordinances and every part of each section is an
independent section and part of a section, and the holding of any section or a
part thereof to be unconstitutional, void or ineffective for any cause does not
affect the validity or constitutionality of any other section or part thereof.
§ 10.99 GENERAL PENALTY.
   Whenever, in the codified ordinances or in any ordinance of the town, any
act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or
whenever the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is
declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is otherwise provided,
whoever violates any such provision shall be fined not more than $500 or
imprisoned not more than 30 days, or both. Each day any such violation
continues shall constitute a separate offense.

11.01   Adoption of seal
§ 11.01 ADOPTION OF SEAL.
   The following seal is hereby adopted as the seal of and for the Town of
Oceana: “TOWN OF OCEANA, W. VA. SEAL”. The words “TOWN OF OCEANA, OCEANA, W.
VA.” shall be written forming a circle with the word “SEAL” in the center
thereof.

Section
   
30.01   Payment due dates for all lease agreements

30.03   Payment of lost firefighters wages
§ 30.01 PAYMENT DUE DATES FOR ALL LEASE AGREEMENTS.
   (A)   Short title. This section shall be known and may be cited as the
“Lease Payment Date Ordinance”.
   (B)   Purposes and findings.
      (1)   The Town Council has determined that there are annual lease fees
paid by citizens of the town for the annual leasing of properties owned by the
town.
      (2)   The Town Council finds and determines that the current payment due
dates for these leases are for several different dates during the calendar year
and are difficult to keep track of.
      (3)   The Town Council has determined that it would be easier if the
payment due dates of all lease agreements of the town was changed to July 1.
   (C)   Determinations. The Town Council hereby changes all lease payment due
dates to July 1, 2012.
   (D)   Violations. A lessee who does not pay the annual lease fee will be in
breach of the lease agreement entered into with the town.
(Ord. passed 6-14-2012)
§ 30.02 PERSONAL USE OF TOWN FUEL AND TOWN VEHICLES BY EMPLOYEES OR ELECTED
OFFICIALS.
   (A)   Short title. This section shall be known and may be cited as the
“Prohibition of Personal Use Ordinance”.
   (B)   Purposes and findings.
      (1)   The Town Council has determined that there is the possibility that
town vehicles and town purchased fuel could be used by both employees and
elected officials for personal use; and
      (2)   The Town Council finds and determines that special and extenuating
circumstances presently exist within this town that call for special regulation
of this personal use.
   (C)   Determinations. The town prohibits the personal use of town fuel and
the personal use of town vehicles for any personal use by an employee or by an
elected official of the town. If an employee uses his or her own vehicle for
town business, then the town will pay that employee mileage at the current IRS
rate. Any such use of a personal vehicle for town business has to be authorized
by the Mayor.
   (D)   Violations.
      (1)   An elected official who uses town vehicles or town purchased fuel
for personal use shall be reported to the state’s Ethics Commission.
      (2)   An employee who uses town vehicles or town purchased fuel for
personal use shall be given reprimands consistent with procedures found within
the Town of Oceana Employee Handbook.
(Ord. passed 6-9-2011)
§ 30.03 PAYMENT OF LOST FIREFIGHTERS WAGES.
   (A)   The Town Council authorizes the Recorder to pay from the General Fund
for any shift or shifts of work lost by a firefighter or firefighters in
pursuit of their duty as volunteer firefighter while fighting a fire inside the
corporate limits of the town.
   (B)   Said firefighter shall be paid in accordance with his or her
prescribed rate of pay might be on the job that he or she is employed at.
   (C)   This rate of pay does not apply to any volunteer firefighter who does
not be necessity in fighting fire lose a shift of work.
(Ord. passed 2-4-1965)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 31.01 COMPENSATION OF ELECTED MUNICIPAL OFFICERS.
   (A)   The Mayor, Town Recorder and the five Council members, each shall be
paid the sum of $200 per month for attendance at regular and specially called
meetings. When a special meeting is not called, the Mayor, Town Recorder and
the five Council members shall receive compensation in the amount of $200 per
month. In no event shall the payment to the Mayor, Town Recorder or each of the
five Council members exceed the sum of $200 each in any calendar month during
their term of office for attendance at a regular or specially called meeting of
the Town Council in any calendar month; provided, however, in addition to the
compensation to be paid to the Mayor and Town Recorder for attendance at the
Council meetings aforesaid, the Mayor shall be paid an additional sum of $500
and the Town Recorder shall be paid an additional sum of $350 for each calendar
month during their terms of office as pay for their services as the Mayor and
Town Recorder of the town.
   (B)   The provisions of this section shall not be applicable to or affect
the salary or compensation of the current municipal officers, and shall become
effective at the beginning of the fiscal year on July 1, 1998.
(Ord. passed 3-10-1988; Ord. passed 5-26-1992; Ord. passed 3-17-1998)
§ 31.02 PROHIBITING FUTURE ELECTED OFFICIALS FROM RECEIVING ANY BENEFIT OTHER
THAN SALARY.
   (A)   Short title. This section shall be known and may be cited as the
“Prohibition of Future Elected Officials From Receiving Benefits Other Than
Salary Ordinance”.
   (B)   Purposes and findings.
      (1)   The Town Council has determined that there is the possibility that
benefits other than salary are being received by elected officials of the town.
      (2)   The Town Council finds and determines that special and extenuating
circumstances presently exist within this town that call for special regulation
of this receipt of benefits other than salary.
   (C)   Determinations. The Town Council hereby prohibits any elected official
of the town from receiving any benefit other than the salary proscribed by
ordinance of the town, in accordance with the laws of the state, with “benefit”
being described as “something that would cost the town money”. An example of a
“benefit” would be a pool pass. The elected official still has the opportunity
to ask for a benefit from the Mayor, Recorder and Town Council.
   (D)   Violations. An elected official who obtains a benefit from the town
without seeking approval of the Mayor, Recorder and Town Council shall be
reported to the state’s Ethics Commission.
(Ord. passed 6-9-2011)
TOWN TREASURER AND RECORDER
§ 31.15 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   RECORDER. Anyone who is elected to fill said position for the town, to
perform the duties of the Mayor of the town when the Mayor is absent or ill.
   TREASURER. The person hired by the Town Council for two- or four-year terms
to perform all financial duties and obligations and to engage in personnel
management responsibilities in cooperation with the Mayor.
(Ord. passed 11-8-2007; Ord. passed 4-10-2008)
§ 31.16 APPLICABILITY.
   It has been determined that this subchapter applies to all individuals who
are elected as Recorder and all individuals who are hired as Treasurer.
(Ord. passed 4-10-2008)
§ 31.17 TREASURER’S DUTIES.
   The Treasurer shall perform the following duties:
   (A)   Administer all financial obligations and duties of the town,
including, but not limited to, the administration of the town’s municipal water
and sewer systems, the development of the budgets for each department of the
town, collecting and managing all funds, all accounting and financial
reporting, and budget preparation; and
   (B)   Personnel management responsibilities in cooperation with the Mayor.
In the event of a conflict between the Mayor and the Recorder, in the duties of
personnel management, the Mayor of the town shall prevail.
(Ord. passed 11-8-2007; Ord. passed 4-10-2008)
§ 31.18 RECORDER’S DUTIES.
   The Recorder shall perform the following duties:
   (A)   Keep the minutes of the regular and special meetings of the Town
Council;
   (B)   Preserve the official minutes, ordinances, resolutions and other
records of the town;
   (C)   All election duties and responsibilities of the town; and
   (D)   The official duties of the Mayor of the town, only when the Mayor of
the town is absent or too ill to perform his or her obligations and only upon
the consent of the Mayor of the town.
(Ord. passed 11-8-2007; Ord. passed 4-10-2008)
§ 31.19 TREASURER GENERALLY.
   (A)   The Council agrees that the Treasurer shall be hired by the Mayor and
approved by a majority vote of the Council and the Mayor.
   (B)   The Council agrees that the Treasurer shall be on the payroll as a
paid employee of the town. The job of Treasurer is to be budgeted as a position
of employment separate from the elected position of Recorder.
   (C)   The Treasurer will be eligible to run for any elected office of the
town.
   (D)   The Treasurer will be an “at will” employee of the town and will be
subject to the Town of Oceana Employee Handbook.
   (E)   The Treasurer shall be a high school graduate and shall have
experience in the field of accounting and/or bookkeeping.
(Ord. passed 11-8-2007; Ord. passed 4-10-2008)
§ 31.20 DISCLOSURE OF EXPENDITURES.
   (A)   For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
      DISCRETIONARY EXPENDITURES. Any expenditure which is outside of the
normal course of business for the town.
      EXPENDITURE. Any expense made by the Treasurer of the town.
   (B)   The Council agrees that the Treasurer shall provide a report to the
Council at each regular meeting of the Town Council which lists each and every
expenditure made by the Treasurer on behalf of the town. When possible and
practicable, the Treasurer shall provide purchase orders to the Town Council
for its approval.
   (C)   The Council agrees that all discretionary expenditures shall be
submitted to the Town Council for discussion and vote prior to funds of the
town being committed for such discretionary expenditure.
   (D)   When there is doubt in anyone’s mind about whether or not an
expenditure falls under the definition of discretionary, that expenditure must
come before the Town Council for discussion and vote prior to funds of the town
being committed for such discretionary expenditure.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010)
§ 31.21 RECORDER SALARY.
   The Recorder will be paid a salary of $200 per month.
(Ord. passed 4-10-2008)
CHAPTER 32: COUNCIL MEETINGS

Open Meetings

32.18   Violations
GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 32.01 POLICY FOR CONDUCT OF COUNCIL MEETINGS REGARDING CITIZEN RECOGNITION.
   (A)   It has been determined that this section applies to all regular,
special and emergency meetings of the Town Council.
   (B)   The Council agrees that after each topic is announced on the agenda
and after each Council person, Recorder, Mayor and Attorney have said what they
want to say about each topic, then members of the public in attendance at the
meeting will be asked to walk quietly and peaceably in a single file line
behind the microphone established for such purpose.
   (C)   The Council agrees to allot each citizen five minutes to speak their
mind and to dialogue with the Council, Recorder, Mayor and Attorney, if
necessary.
   (D)   The Council agrees that everyone shall speak in a one at a time
manner. No boisterous or excessively loud conduct will be allowed. Rudeness to
anyone will not be tolerated.
   (E)   The Council agrees that no one will be allowed to speak unless they
are standing behind the microphone established for such purpose. No one will be
permitted to speak or yell from the chair in which they are sitting.
   (F)   (1)   If in the determination of a majority of the Town Council, such
member of the public is conducting himself or herself in a manner which is in
violation of this section, then the member of the public will be asked to
leave.
      (2)   If the member of the public does not leave voluntarily, then a
member of the town’s Police Department will be asked to escort said member of
the public out of the meeting and away from town property.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010)
OPEN MEETINGS
§ 32.15 SHORT TITLE.
   This subchapter shall be known and may be cited as the “Open Governmental
Meetings Act Ordinance”.
(Ord. passed 9-9-2010)
§ 32.16 PURPOSES AND FINDINGS.
   (A)   The Town Council has determined that there is the possibility that
elected officials of the town could conduct meetings without notice as required
by West Virginia law.
   (B)   The Town Council finds and determines that special and extenuating
circumstances presently exist within this town that call for regulation of any
meetings held without notice to the public.
(Ord. passed 9-9-2010)
§ 32.17 DETERMINATIONS.
   The Town Council hereby adopts the Open Governmental Meetings Act, as
contained within W. Va. Code §§ 6-9A-l et seq., and intends to follow the
guidelines established in this Act when completing an agenda for a meeting and
when conducting a regular or special Council meeting.
(Ord. passed 9-9-2010)
§ 32.18 VIOLATIONS.
   An elected official who violates the Open Governmental Meetings Act, being
W. Va. Code Chapter 6, Article 9A, shall be reported to the state’s Ethics
Commission.
(Ord. passed 9-9-2010)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 33.01 SHORT TITLE.
   This chapter may be sited as the “Town of Oceana Purchasing Ordinance”.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010; Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 33.02 PURPOSE.
   The purpose for this chapter is to provide for an efficient and equitable
system of public purchasing by the town; to obtain the maximum purchasing value
of public funds in procurement system of quality and integrity; and, to provide
for selling surplus goods in a manner which is efficient and equitable and
yields the highest sale price.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010; Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 33.03 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CHAPTER. Sections
33.01 through
33.08,
33.20 through
33.30 and
33.45 through
33.48 of this code of ordinances.
   CONTRACT. Any town agreement, regardless of form or title, for the
procurement or disposition of goods.
   GIFTS or FAVORS. Anything of any service or value.
   GOODS. Supplies, apparatus, materials, equipment and other forms of tangible
personal property.
   MAYOR. The Mayor of the Town of Oceana.
   PURCHASING AGENT. The person designated as a purchasing agent pursuant to §
33.04 of this chapter.
   TOWN. The Town of Oceana
   TOWN COUNCIL. The governing board of the Town of Oceana.
   TREASURER. The Treasurer of the Town of Oceana.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010; Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 33.04 PURCHASING AGENT.
   (A)   The Treasurer shall have the responsibilities and powers of the
purchasing agent under this chapter; provided, however, the Treasurer may
delegate some or all the responsibilities and powers to a subordinate town
employee and may designate the employee as purchasing agent.
   (B)   (1)   The purchasing agent shall serve as such at the pleasure of the
Treasurer. Any such delegation shall be in writing, shall be filed in the
office of Treasurer, and shall be available for public inspection in the manner
provided by law.
      (2)   If the Treasurer reserves any power or responsibility for himself
or herself, that reservation shall be expressed in the written delegation
statement filed with the Treasurer’s office.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010; Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 33.05 POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE PURCHASING AGENT.
   The purchasing agent shall have the following powers and duties:
   (A)   (1)   Procure or oversee the procurement of all goods needed by the
town and advertise for bids of such goods.
      (2)   Consistent with this chapter and subject to the approval of the
Council, Recorder, and Mayor, the purchasing agent may adopt operating
procedures relating to purchase of goods for the town and may publish a
handbook containing those procedures;
   (B)   Provide for and oversee, the development of specifications for goods
purchased by the town, administer purchase contracts to which the town is a
party, and provide for inspecting and accepting goods purchased by the town;
   (C)   Process all claims for loss, damage, breakage or shortage, or claims
for refund and adjustment concerning the purchase of goods for the town;
   (D)   Exercise general supervision and control over all inventories and
goods belonging to the town and provide for the transfer between town
departments of surplus goods;
   (E)   Require bonds, insurance and other forms of protection for the town in
the process of procuring goods for the town;
   (F)   Terminate solicitations for bids when, in the opinion of the Town
Council, it is in the town’s best interest to do so;
   (G)   Reject any and all bids when, in the opinion of the Town Council, it
is in the town’s best interest to do so;
   (H)   Following consultation with the Town Attorney, terminate contracts or
pursue other remedies when the party or parties with whom the town is
contracting has, or have, breached the contract;
   (I)   Sell, lease or dispose of goods and personal property of the town as
prescribed in W. Va. Code § 8-12-18; and
   (J)   Perform such other duties as the Treasurer shall direct.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010; Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 33.06 PRE-AUDIT CERTIFICATION.
   (A)   The purchasing agent shall not approve any contract for the purchase
of goods until the Treasurer certifies, after pre-audit, that there is to the
credit of the using department or agency, a sufficient unencumbered
appropriation balance in excess of all unpaid obligations, to defray the amount
of such order.
   (B)   Subject to the approval of the Treasurer, the purchasing agent may
issue operation rules to ensure compliance with this section.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010; Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 33.07 GIFTS AND FAVORS PROHIBITED.
   The purchasing agent and every officer and employee of the town whose duties
involve the purchasing and selling of goods, or the preparation of
specifications for the purchase of goods for the town, are expressly prohibited
from engaging in any activity or accepting any gift or favor that is prohibited
by the West Virginia Governmental Ethics Act, being W. Va. Code Chapter 6B,
Article 1.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010; Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 33.08 EVASION PROHIBITED.
   No purchase of sale shall be divided for the purpose of evading the
provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010; Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
PROCUREMENT
§ 33.20 SMALL PURCHASES.
   The purchasing agent shall establish procedures for the purchases of goods
involving the estimated expenditure of less than $1,000 of public money. These
procedures shall require that competition be sought and written records be
adequate to document that the competition be maintained in order to properly
account for the funds expended, and facilitate an audit of the small purchases
made.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010; Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 33.21 PURCHASES BASED ON FORMAL BIDS.
   Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, no contract for the purchase
of goods involving the estimated expenditure of $1,000 or more of public money
shall be awarded unless the provisions of this section are complied with.
   (A)   Proposals shall be invited by advertisement in a newspaper having
general circulation in the town. The advertisement shall state the time and
place for opening of the bids. At least seven full days must pass between the
day the advertisement appears and the day of the bid opening. The advertisement
shall state the town reserves the right to reject any and/or all of the bid.
   (B)   (1)   The purchasing agent may require that bid deposits be submitted
with each bid. If bid deposits are required, they shall be in an amount equal
to 5% of the amount of the bid and may be submitted in the form of:
         (a)   Cash;
         (b)   A cashier’s check;
         (c)   A certified check by a bank or trust company insured by the
federal deposit insurance corporation; or
         (d)   A bid bond or other form of bid security deemed sufficient by
the Town Attorney.
      (2)   The bid bond requirement, including the form in which bonds or
other forms of bid security may be submitted, shall be included in the
specifications.
   (C)   Bids shall be sealed. The purchasing agent shall establish rules
regarding the acceptance of bids by facsimile, and such rules shall comply with
the state code and be on file with the Treasurer’s office.
   (D)   All bids shall be open in public and the purchasing agent shall make a
record of the bids received. The record and the bids received shall be subject
to public inspection after the bid opening in the manner prescribed by law.
   (E)   The purchasing agent may require the successful bidder to furnish a
performance bond to secure the faithful performance of all the terms of the
contract. The performance bond shall be in the form approved by the Town
Attorney, and the form of the bond shall be made in subject to division (A) of
this section. The Town Council may reject the bond of any bidder if they find
it to be unacceptable for any reason.
   (F)   Upon receipt of the bids, the Town Council shall review and recommend
award of the contract as it may determine. All contracts to which this section
applies shall be subject to approval by the Town Council. The Town Council may
reject any and all bids.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010; Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 33.22 EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   The provisions of this chapter do not apply to the purchase of goods
when:
      (1)   A good is available from only one source of supply; and
      (2)   A special emergency exists involving the health and safety of the
people and their property.
   (B)   (1)   The Treasurer shall prepare and submit to the Town Council a
written report concerning any purchase to be made pursuant to this section, and
such purchases shall be subject to approval or ratification by the Town
Council.
      (2)   The Town Council may keep a record of all purchases made pursuant
to this section, and these records shall be subject to public inspection in the
manner provided by law.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010; Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 33.23 AWARD CREDIT FOR LOCAL MERCHANTS.
   Purchases shall be made from, and contracts shall be awarded to, the lowest
responsible bidder meeting bid specifications; provided, that, in determining
the lowest responsible bidder, a competitive advantage of 5% shall be afforded
to the bidders with mercantile establishments situated within the town and who
pay a town business and occupation tax and are current in its accounts to the
town, with such 5% competitive advantage to be based upon the gross amount of
the bid received from the local merchant.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010; Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 33.24 WAIVER BASED ON THE OTHER GOVERNMENT PURCHASES.
   (A)   When the Town Council determines that it is in the best interest of
the town, the requirements of this chapter may be waived for the purchase of
goods from any person or entity that has, within the previous 12 months, after
completed a public, formal bid process substantially similar to that prescribed
in §
33.21 of this chapter, contracted to furnish the goods to:
      (1)   The United States of America or any federal agency; or
      (2)   This state or any agency or political subdivision of this state;
provided the person or entity is willing to furnish the goods at the same or
more favorable prices, terms and conditions as those described under the
contract with the other unit or agency.
   (B)   Any purchase made under this section shall be approved or ratified by
the Town Council at a meeting of the Town Council.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010; Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 33.25 PROCUREMENT; PROFESSIONAL SERVICES.
   For the purpose of procuring the services of accountants, clergy,
physicians, lawyers, dentists, industrial hygienists, appraisers or other
professionals, professional service contracts shall be the responsibility of
the Town Council to employ such individuals or firms within the limit of funds
available for lawful town purposes. Any department, board or commission of the
town may contract for such services without competitive procedures and without
requiring a performance surety.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010; Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 33.26 CONTRACTS FOR ARCHITECTURAL AND ENGINEERING SERVICES; SELECTION PROCESS
WHERE TOTAL PROJECT COST ARE ESTIMATED TO COST $250,000 OR MORE.
   (A)   In the procurement of architectural and engineering services;
selection process where total project cost are estimated to cost $250,000 or
more, the Treasurer shall encourage such firms engaged in the lawful practice
of the profession to submit an expression of interest, which shall include a
statement of qualifications and performance data and may include anticipated
concepts and proposed methods of approach to the project.
   (B)   (1)   All such jobs shall be announced by public notice published as a
Class II legal advertisement in compliance with provisions of W. Va. Code §§
59-3-1 et seq. A committee of at least three representatives of the town,
including Council members and the Mayor, shall evaluate the statements of
qualifications and performance data and other material submitted by interested
firms and select a minimum of three firms which, in their opinion, are best
qualified to perform the desired service. Interviews with each firm selected
shall be conducted, and the committee shall conduct discussions regarding
anticipated concepts and proposed methods of approach to the assignment.
      (2)   The committee shall then rank, in order of preference, not less
than three professional firms deemed to be the most highly qualified to provide
the services required.
   (C)   The Mayor shall commence scope of service and price negotiations with
the highest qualified professional firm or the architectural or engineering
services or both, which agreement shall be approved by the Town Council before
the town may enter into a binding contract.
   (D)   (1)   Should the Mayor be unable to negotiate a satisfactory contract
with the firm considered to be the most qualified at a fee determined to be
fair and reasonable, price negotiations with the firm of the second choice
shall commence.
      (2)   Failing accord with the second most qualified professional firm,
the Mayor shall undertake price negotiations with the third most qualified
professional firm.
   (E)   Should the Mayor be unable to negotiate a satisfactory contract with
any of the selected firms, then the committee shall select additional
professional firms in order of their competence and qualifications, and the
Mayor shall continue negotiations in accordance with this section until the
agreement is reached.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010; Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 33.27 CONTRACTS FOR ARCHITECTURAL AND ENGINEERING SERVICES; SELECTION PROCESS
WHERE TOTAL PROJECT COSTS ARE ESTIMATED TO COST LESS THAN $250,000.
   (A)   (1)   In the procurement of architectural and engineering services;
selection process where total project cost are estimated to cost less than
$250,000, competition shall be sought by the town.
      (2)   The Mayor shall conduct discussions with three or more professional
firms solicited on the basis of known or submitted qualifications for the
assignment prior to the awarding of any contract: provided, that if a judgement
is made that special circumstances exists and that seeking competition is not
practical, the Mayor may, with the prior approval of the Council, select a firm
on the basis of previous satisfactory performance and knowledge of the town’s
facilities and needs.
   (B)   After selection, the Town Council, the Mayor and the firm shall
develop the scope of services required and negotiate an agreement which shall
be approved by the Town Council before the town may enter into a binding
contract.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010; Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 33.28 TIE BIDS.
   In the event of a tie, ties shall be resolved by the flip of a coin
performed during a meeting of the Town Council.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010; Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 33.29 NON-DISCRIMINATION POLICY.
   In every case, all contracts shall be made and purchases shall be awarded
without regard to race, religion, political affiliation, sex, handicap or
national origin.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010; Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 33.30 RESERVATIONS.
   Whether or not expressly set forth in the notice of solicitation for
bidding, the town shall be privileged and hereby reserves the right to reject
any and all bids and further reserves the right, at its sole discretion, to
determine whether a bidder is responsible based upon past performances and the
best information available at the time of the awarding of the contract or
purchase order.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010; Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
OTHER REGULATIONS
§ 33.45 INTERGOVERNMENTAL AGREEMENTS, CONTRACTS WITH OTHER GOVERNMENTAL
AGENCIES.
   If the town enters into an intergovernmental agreement or contract with
another governmental agency as permitted by state law, the provisions of this
chapter shall apply unless the agreement or contract contains express
provisions for the procurement of goods, in which case, if the
intergovernmental agreement or contract was adopted by ordinance as required by
W. Va. Code § 8-11-3(10), the procurement terms of the agreement or contract
shall apply.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010; Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 33.46 SEVERABILITY.
   The provisions of this chapter are declared to be severable. If any section,
sentence, clause or phrase of this chapter shall, for any reason, be held to be
invalid or unconstitutional by a court of competent jurisdiction, such decision
shall not affect the remaining sections, sentences, clauses and phrases of this
chapter, but they shall remain in effect; it being the legislative intent that
this chapter shall remain in effect notwithstanding the validity of any part.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010; Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 33.47 RECEIPT OF FEDERAL OR STATE FUNDS.
   If any requirement of the provisions set forth in this chapter jeopardizes
the receipt of federal or state funds, then such requirements or provision
shall be void and of no force or effect for that specific project.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010; Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 33.48 AMENDMENT.
   The amendment to the purchasing ordinance of the town is as follows: a three
step process of documentation of purchases should be implemented when a repair
of either real or personal property belonging to the town is needed. First, a
work order is to be completed, which details the problem to be fixed and/or
repaired. Second, a purchase order is to be completed, which details the parts
needed to repair the issue addressed by the work order along with the cost of
each individual item listed on the purchase order. Third, a job completion
statement is to be created, which details which part went to fix what problem.
If entered into a computer program, then all efforts will need to be made to
see that the above information is entered into the computer program with
sufficient detail to accomplish the intention of this amendment.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2010; Ord. passed 7-12-2012)

MUNICIPAL ELECTION; OFFICERS AND FILING FEES
§ 34.01 AUTHORITY, FINDINGS AND DETERMINATIONS.
   (A)   Authority. This subchapter is adopted pursuant to the provisions of W.
Va. Code Chapter 8, Article 5, § 5, and Chapter 8, Article 11, §§ 1 et seq.,
and amendments thereto, and other applicable provisions of law.
   (B)   Findings and determinations. It is hereby found, determined and
declared as follows:
“That under the provisions of Chapter 8, Article 5, Section 5 of the West
Virginia Code, as amended, the regular election of officers of a city, town, or
village is required to be held on the first Tuesday in May of the appropriate
year; and that in 1981, the West Virginia Legislature, under Code 3-5-1,
changed the date of the State primary election from the first Tuesday in May of
the appropriate year; that the Town of Oceana does not maintain separate books
and uses the county registration books in its elections and the voting precinct
boundaries of the town does not coincide with the voting precinct boundaries
established by the county commission; and that the conflict in the election by
the Town of Oceana on the first Tuesday in May and the State primary election
on the second Tuesday in May results in the unavailability of the voters
registration records and books and the polling place for the municipal election
for the Town of Oceana and precludes the Town of Oceana from carrying out its
duties with reference to the regular municipal election; and, it is necessary
to provide that the municipal election of the Town of Oceana be held on some
day other than the first Tuesday in May.”
(Ord. passed 4-3-1986)
§ 34.02 TIME AND PLACE.
   It is hereby declared that the regular election for the office of Mayor,
Town Recorder and five Members of the Town Council shall be held on the first
Tuesday in May in the year 1980, and thereafter on the first Tuesday in May of
the appropriate year, at which election the officers shall be elected for a
four-year term.
(Ord. 3-24-1980; Ord. passed 4-3-1986; Ord. passed - -2024)
Cross-reference:
   Term of elected officials, see §
34.06
§ 34.03 FILING ANNOUNCEMENT OF CANDIDACIES; REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Any person who is eligible to hold and seeks to hold the office of
Mayor, Town Recorder or Council Member of the town shall file with the Town
Recorder of the town, a certificate declaring himself or herself as a candidate
for such office in form or effect as required by general law.
   (B)   Such certificate shall be filed with the Town Recorder not earlier
than the second Monday in the month of February next preceding the election day
to be held on the second Tuesday in the month of June of the election year, and
not later than the first Friday of March next preceding the election day, and
must be received before the close of the business day, eastern standard time,
of that day, or if mailed, shall be postmarked before that hour, in each
appropriate election year.
   (C)   The provisions of this section shall apply to the municipal election
held in the year 1986 and every municipal election held thereafter, until the
date of holding the municipal elections are changed by statute duly enacted by
the state legislature enabling the town to hold its election not in conflict
with the state primary election, or by an order of a court of competent
jurisdiction.
(Ord. passed 4-3-1986)
§ 34.04 MUNICIPAL ELECTION CANDIDATE FILING FEES.
   (A)   The Town Council has determined that there are filing fees for an
elected office of the town.
   (B)   The Town Council has determined that the current fees are not in
compliance with the fees recommended to be charged by the Secretary of State’s
office, with said recommendation being 1% of the annual salary of the
particular office filed for.
   (C)   The Town Council hereby increases the filing fees for a candidate
seeking election to a municipal office of the town to the following rates:
 
Mayor    $96
Recorder $66
Council  $24
 
   (D)   A candidate for an elected office of the town who does not pay the
filing fee will not be placed upon the ballot to run for the office he or she
desires.
(Ord. passed 4-3-1986; Ord. passed 10-13-2016)
§ 34.05 GENERAL LAW CONCERNING OFFICES AND ELECTIONS; NOTICE AND PUBLICATION.
   (A)   Except as otherwise provided in this subchapter, the provisions of
general laws with respect to the method and time for the filing of certificates
of candidacy, conducting municipal elections, and determining and certifying
the results of such elections, so far as appropriate, shall apply to the
municipal elections of the town.
   (B)   Notice of the municipal election shall be given during the two weeks
next preceding the election by publication of a sample official ballot as a
Class II-0 legal advertisement in compliance with the provisions of W. Va. Code
§§ 59-3-1 et seq. and Chapter 59, and the publication area for such publication
shall be the town. The second publication shall be on the last day upon which
each newspaper is published before the election.
(Ord. passed 4-3-1986)
§ 34.06 TERM OF ELECTED OFFICIALS.
   Elected officials shall be elected to serve a four-year term beginning July
first following the election.
(Ord. passed 4-3-1986)
§ 34.07 REFUND OF FILING FEES.
   (A)   Short title. This section shall be known and may be cited as the
“Filing Fee Refund Ordinance”.
   (B)   Purposes and findings.
      (1)   The Town Council has determined that there are filing fees paid by
citizens of the town for the privilege of declaring a candidacy for an elected
office of the town.
      (2)   The Town Council finds and determines that some individuals who
file for candidacy later are excluded from the ballot or voluntarily withdraw
their name from the ballot.
      (3)   The Town Council has determined that it would be fair and equitable
to allow such individuals to be refunded their filing fees.
   (C)   Determinations. The Town Council hereby mandates that all filing fees
be refunded for any candidate who has voluntarily withdrawn from candidacy and
any candidate who has been excluded from the ballot for any reason.
   (D)   Exclusions. This section would not allow individuals who run for
office and then are subsequently elected to be refunded any filing fees and
would not allow individuals who serve either part or all of their elected terms
to be refunded any filing fees.
(Ord. passed 6-14-2012)
PAYMENT OF ELECTION POLL WORKERS
§ 34.15 SHORT TITLE.
   This subchapter shall be known and may be cited as the “Poll Worker Payment
Ordinance”.
(Ord. passed 8-9-2012)
§ 34.16 PURPOSES AND FINDINGS.
   The Town Council has determined that there needs to be a procedure followed
by the town when the Recorder hires poll workers and the Treasurer pays for the
services of said poll workers.
(Ord. passed 8-9-2012)
§ 34.17 DETERMINATIONS.
   The Town Council hereby implements the following procedures for the payment
of poll workers.
   (A)   Each poll worker and alternate poll worker who attends training for an
election will receive $75 for successful completion of the training.
   (B)   No payment for successful completion of training will be issued by the
Treasurer until the completion of the election. In other words, no poll worker
or alternate poll worker will be paid for their training participation until
after the election is completed.
   (C)   Alternates who successfully complete the training for an election but
who do not serve as a poll worker will still be paid $75 for their successful
completion of the training but only after the election has been completed.
   (D)   Each poll worker who successfully serves the entire election day will
be paid $75, after the election is completed.
   (E)   Each early voter poll worker will be paid the current minimum wage for
each hour that they serve during the early voting period and will be paid for
their successful completion of the early voting service to the town after the
election has been completed.
   (F)   The Recorder, seeing a need for a variance to the above payment
schedule and amounts, or seeing budgetary restrictions or surpluses, can ask
the Council of the town for permission to increase payment, decrease payment or
make other variances to divisions (A) through (E) of this section.
(Ord. passed 8-9-2012)
§ 34.18 VIOLATIONS.
   Any employee who does not comply with this poll worker payment subchapter is
subject to disciplinary procedures from the Town of Oceana Employee Handbook.
(Ord. passed 8-9-2012)
