GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 36.001 ADOPTION OF NIMS.
   The town does hereby establish the National Incident Management System
(NIMS) as the town standard for incident management.
§ 36.002 MAINTENANCE OF PERSONAL VEHICLES ON TOWN OWNED PROPERTY.
   (A)   Short title. This section shall be known and may be cited as the
“Prohibition of Maintenance of Personal Vehicles on Town Owned Property”.
   (B)   Purposes and findings. The Town Council has determined that there is
the possibility that personal vehicles are being maintenanced on town owned
property. The Town Council finds and determines that special and extenuating
circumstances presently exist within this town that call for special regulation
of this maintenance of personal vehicles on city owned property.
   (C)   Determinations. The Town Council prohibits maintenance and repair of
personal vehicles on the real estate owned by the town. This maintenance and
repair includes, but is not limited to, the washing of vehicles, oil changes,
body work and mechanic work. There shall be no mechanic work performed by
anyone on anyone else’s vehicles on property owned by the town. The only
exemption from this section is if the personal vehicle of an employee or an
elected official or a member of the public does not start once it has been
parked at the Town Hall. Then, all measures can be performed to get the vehicle
running once again in order to remove it from the property at the Town Hall.
   (D)   Violations.
      (1)   An elected official who uses city vehicles or city purchased fuel
for personal use shall be reported to the West Virginia Ethics Commission.
      (2)   An employee who uses city vehicles or city purchased fuel for
personal use shall be given a letter of reprimand and discipline procedures
found within the Town of Oceana Employee Handbook shall be followed.
(Ord. passed 6-9-2011)
REIMBURSEMENT OF POSTAGE EXPENSES FOR ATTORNEY
§ 36.015 SHORT TITLE.
   This subchapter shall be known and may be cited as the “Attorney Expense
Reimbursement Ordinance”.
(Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 36.016 PURPOSES AND FINDINGS.
   The Town Council has determined that there needs to be a procedure followed
by the town when the Attorney pays for the delivery of mail on behalf of the
town.
(Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 36.017 DETERMINATION.
   The Town Council hereby implements the following procedures for the
reimbursement of the Attorney’s postage expenses.
   (A)   At each Council meeting, the Attorney will present copies of envelopes
to verify the postage expenses for the previous month.
   (B)   The Council, Mayor, Recorder and Treasurer can review the copies of
the envelopes mailed on behalf of the town by the Attorney.
   (C)   The Attorney will report to the Council, Mayor, Recorder and Treasurer
the total expense of the postage and will present an invoice to the Treasurer.
   (D)   The Treasurer will pay the Attorney’s invoice as soon as reasonably
possible.
   (E)   The Attorney can present other expenses from time to time to the
Council, such as mileage to a particular meeting, enrollment fees for municipal
classes, or other municipally related expenses and is not limited solely to
reimbursement for postage.
(Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 36.018 VIOLATIONS.
   Any employee who does not comply with this reimbursement subchapter is
subject to disciplinary procedures from the Town of Oceana Employee Handbook.
(Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
PROHIBITION OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS ON TOWN-OWNED PROPERTY
§ 36.030 SHORT TITLE.
   This subchapter shall be known and may be cited as the “Prohibition of
Tobacco Products Ordinance”.
(Ord. passed 9-13-2012)
§ 36.031 PURPOSES AND FINDINGS.
   The Town Council has determined that there needs to be a policy followed by
the town for the usage of tobacco products.
(Ord. passed 9-13-2012)
§ 36.032 DETERMINATIONS.
   The Town Council hereby implements the following policy.
   (A)   There shall be no tobacco products used inside town buildings,
including town hall, the town pool, the water plant, the sewer plant and any
other town buildings, with the exclusion of the building occupied by the town’s
Fire Department.
   (B)   TOBACCO PRODUCTS are defined as the following but are not limited to:
cigarettes; cigars; chewing tobacco; and snuff.
(Ord. passed 9-13-2012)
§ 36.033 VIOLATIONS.
   Any employee who does not comply with this reimbursement ordinance is
subject to disciplinary procedures from the Town of Oceana Employee Handbook.
(Ord. passed 9-13-2012)
IDENTITY THEFT PREVENTION PROGRAM
§ 36.045 SHORT TITLE.
   This subchapter shall be known as the Identity Theft Prevention Program.
(Ord. passed 9-9-2010)
§ 36.046 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this subchapter is to comply with 16 C.F.R. § 681.2 in order
to detect, prevent and mitigate identity theft by identifying and detecting
identity theft red flags and by responding to such red flags in a manner that
will prevent identity theft.
(Ord. passed 9-9-2010)
§ 36.047 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. Other
than “town” and “personal identifying information”, definitions provided in
this section are based on the definitions provided in 16 C.F.R. § 681.2.
   COVERED ACCOUNT.
      (1)   An account that a financial institution or creditor offers or
maintains, primarily for personal, family or household purposes, that involves
or is designed to permit multiple payments or transactions, such as a credit
card account, mortgage loan, automobile loan, margin account, cell phone
account, utility account, checking account, or savings account; and
      (2)   Any other account that the financial institution or creditor offers
or maintains for which there is a reasonably foreseeable risk to customers or
to the safety and soundness of the financial institution or creditor from
identity theft, including financial, operational, compliance, reputation or
litigation risks.
   CREDIT. The right granted by a creditor to a debtor to defer payment of debt
or to incur debts and defer its payment or to purchase property or services and
defer payment therefore.
   CREDITOR. Any person who regularly extends, renews or continues credit; any
person who regularly arranges for the extension, renewal, or continuation of
credit; or any assignee of an original creditor who participates in the
decision to extend, renew, or continue credit and includes utility companies
and telecommunications companies.
   CUSTOMER. A person that has a covered account with a creditor.
   IDENTITY THEFT. A fraud committed or attempted using identifying information
of another person without authority.
   PERSON. A natural person, a corporation, government or governmental
subdivision or agency, trust, estate, partnership, cooperative or association.
   PERSONAL IDENTIFYING INFORMATION. A person’s credit card account
information, debit card information bank account information and drivers’
license information and for a natural person includes their Social Security
number, mother’s birth name and date of birth.
   RED FLAG. A pattern, practice or specific activity that indicates the
possible existence of identity theft.
   SERVICE PROVIDER. A person that provides a service directly to the town.
   TOWN. The Town of Oceana.
(Ord. passed 9-9-2010)
§ 36.048 FINDINGS.
   (A)   The town is a creditor pursuant to 16 C.F.R. § 681.2 due to its
provision or maintenance of covered accounts for which payment is made in
arrears.
   (B)   Covered accounts offered to customers for the provision of town
services include water, sewer and garbage.
   (C)   The city’s previous experience with identity theft related to covered
accounts is as follows: none.
   (D)   The processes of opening a new covered account, restoring an existing
covered account, making payments on such accounts have been identified as
potential processes in which identity theft could occur.
   (E)   (1)   The town limits access to personal identifying information to
those employees responsible for or otherwise involved in opening or restoring
covered accounts or accepting payment for use of covered accounts.
      (2)   Information provided to such employees is entered directly into the
city’s computer system and is not otherwise recorded.
   (F)   The town determines that there is a low risk of identity theft
occurring in the following ways (if any):
      (1)   Use by an applicant of another person’s personal identifying
information to establish a new covered account;
      (2)   Use of a previous customer’s personal identifying information by
another person in an effort to have service restored in the previous customer’s
name;
      (3)   Use of another person’s credit card, bank account or other method
of payment by a customer to pay such customer’s covered account or accounts;
and
      (4)   Use by a customer desiring to restore such customer’s covered
account of another person’s credit card, bank account, or other method of
payment.
(Ord. passed 9-9-2010)
§ 36.049 PROCESS OF ESTABLISHING A COVERED ACCOUNT.
   (A)   (1)   As a precondition to opening a covered account in the town, each
applicant shall provide the town with personal identifying information of the
customer, including a valid government issued identification card containing a
photograph of the customer or, for customers who are not natural persons, a
photograph of the customer’s agent opening the account.
      (2)   Such applicant shall also provide any information necessary for the
department providing the service for which the covered account is created to
access the applicant’s consumer credit report. Such information shall be
entered directly into the city’s computer system and shall not otherwise be
recorded.
   (B)   Each account shall be assigned an account number and personal
identification number (PIN) which shall be unique to that account. The town may
utilize computer software to randomly generate assigned PINs and to encrypt
account numbers and PINs.
(Ord. passed 9-9-2010)
§ 36.050 ACCESS TO COVERED ACCOUNT INFORMATION.
   (A)   Access to customer accounts shall be password protected and shall be
limited to authorized town personnel.
   (B)   Such password(s) shall be changed by the Town Treasurer on a regular
basis, shall be at least eight characters in length and shall contain letters,
numbers and symbols.
   (C)   Any unauthorized access to or other breach of customer accounts is to
be reported immediately to the Town Treasurer and Police Chief and the password
changed immediately.
   (D)   Personal identifying information included in customer accounts is
considered confidential and any request or demand for such information shall be
immediately forwarded to the Town Treasurer and the Town Attorney.
(Ord. passed 9-9-2010)
§ 36.051 CREDIT CARD PAYMENTS.
   In the event that credit card payments that are made over the internet are
processed through a third party service provider, such third party service
provider shall certify that it has an adequate identity theft prevention
program in place that is applicable to such payments. All credit card payments
made over the telephone or the city’s website shall be entered directly into
the customer’s account information in the computer data base. Account
statements and receipts for covered accounts shall include only the last four
digits of the credit or debit card or the bank account used for payment of the
covered account.
(Ord. passed 9-9-2010)
§ 36.052 SOURCES AND TYPES OF RED FLAGS.
   All employees responsible for or involved in the process of opening a
covered account, restoring a covered account or accepting payment for a covered
account shall check for red flags as indicators of possible identity theft and
such red flags may include:
   (A)   Alerts from consumer reporting agencies, fraud detection agencies or
service providers. Examples of alerts include, but are not limited to:
      (1)   A fraud or active duty alert that is included with a consumer
report;
      (2)   A notice of credit freeze in response to a request for a consumer
report;
      (3)   A notice of address discrepancy provided by a consumer reporting
agency;
      (4)   Indications of a pattern of activity in a consumer report that is
inconsistent with the history and usual pattern of activity of an applicant or
customer, such as:
         (a)   A recent and significant increase in the volume of inquiries;
         (b)   An unusual number of recently established credit relationships;
         (c)   A material change in the use of credit, especially with respect
to recently established credit relationships; or
         (d)   An account that was closed for cause or identified for abuse of
account privileges by a financial institution or creditor.
   (B)   Suspicious documents. Examples of suspicious documents include:
      (1)   Documents provided for identification that appear to be altered or
forged;
      (2)   Identification on which the photograph or physical description is
inconsistent with the appearance of the applicant or customer;
      (3)   Identification on which the information is inconsistent with
information provided by the applicant or customer;
      (4)   Identification on which the information is inconsistent with
readily accessible information that is on file with the financial institution
or creditor, such as a signature card or a recent check; or
      (5)   An application that appears to have been altered or forged, or
appears to have been destroyed and reassembled.
   (C)   Suspicious personal identification, such as suspicious address change.
Examples of suspicious identifying information include:
      (1)   Personal identifying information that is inconsistent with external
information sources used by the financial institution or creditor. For example:
         (a)   The address does not match any address in the consumer report;
or
         (b)   The Social Security number (SSN) has not been issued, or is
listed on the Social Security Administration’s Death Master File.
      (2)   Personal identifying information provided by the customer is not
consistent with other personal identifying information provided by the
customer, such as a lack of correlation between the SSN range and date of
birth;
      (3)   Personal identifying information or a phone number or address, is
associated with known fraudulent applications or activities as indicated by
internal or third-party sources used by the financial institution or creditor;
      (4)   Other information provided, such as fictitious mailing address,
mail drop addresses, jail addresses, invalid phone numbers, pager numbers or
answering services, is associated with fraudulent activity;
      (5)   The SSN provided is the same as that submitted by other applicants
or customers;
      (6)   The address or telephone number provided is the same as or similar
to the account number or telephone number submitted by an unusually large
number of applicants or customers;
      (7)   The applicant or customer fails to provide all required personal
identifying information on an application or in response to notification that
the application is incomplete;
      (8)   Personal identifying information is not consistent with personal
identifying information that is on file with the financial institution or
creditor; and
      (9)   The applicant or customer cannot provide authenticating information
beyond that which generally would be available from a wallet or consumer
report.
   (D)   Unusual use of or suspicious activity relating to a covered account.
Examples of suspicious activity include:
      (1)   Shortly following the notice of a change of address for an account,
the town receives a request for the addition of authorized users on the
account;
      (2)   A new revolving credit account is used in a manner commonly
associated with known patterns of fraud patterns. For example, the customer
fails to make the first payment or makes an initial payment but no subsequent
payments;
      (3)   An account is used in a manner that is not consistent with
established patterns of activity on the account. There is, for example:
         (a)   Nonpayment when there is no history of late or missed payments;
and
         (b)   A material change in purchasing or spending patterns.
      (4)   An account that has been inactive for a long period of time is used
(taking into consideration the type of account, the expected pattern of usage
and other relevant factors);
      (5)   Mail sent to the customer is returned repeatedly as undeliverable
although transactions continue to be conducted in connection with the
customer’s account;
      (6)   The town is notified that the customer is not receiving paper
account statements;
      (7)   The town is notified of unauthorized charges or transactions in
connection with a customer’s account; and
      (8)   The town is notified by a customer, law enforcement or another
person that it has opened a fraudulent account for a person engaged in identity
theft.
   (E)   Notice from customers, law enforcement, victims or other reliable
sources regarding possible identity theft or phishing relating to covered
accounts.
(Ord. passed 9-9-2010)
§ 36.053 PREVENTION AND MITIGATION OF IDENTITY THEFT.
   (A)   In the event that any town employee responsible for or involved in
restoring an existing covered account or accepting payment for a covered
account becomes aware of red flags indicating possible identity theft with
respect to existing covered accounts, such employee shall use his or her
discretion to determine whether such red flag or combination of red flags
suggests a threat of identity theft. If, in his or her discretion, such
employee determines that identity theft or attempted identity theft is likely
or probable, such employee shall immediately report such red flags to the
Council. If his or her discretion, such employee deems that identity theft is
unlikely or that reliable information is available to reconcile red flags, the
employee shall convey this information to Council, who may in his or her
discretion determine that no further action is necessary. If Council in his or
her discretion determines that further action is necessary, a town employee
shall perform one or more of the following responses, as determined to be
appropriate by Council:
      (1)   Contact the customer;
      (2)   Make the following changes to the account if, after contacting the
customer, it is apparent that someone other than the customer has accessed the
customer’s covered account:
         (a)   Change any account numbers, passwords, security codes or other
security devices that permit access to an account; or
         (b)   Close the account.
      (3)   Cease attempts to collect additional charges from the customer and
decline to sell the customer’s account to a debt collector in the event that
the customer’s account has been accessed without authorization and such access
has caused additional charges to accrue;
      (4)   Notify a debt collector within 24 hours of the discovery of likely
or probable identity theft relating to a customer account that has been sold to
such debt collector in the event that a customer’s account has been sold to a
debt collector prior to the discovery of the likelihood or probability of
identity theft relating to such account;
      (5)   Notify law enforcement, in the event that someone other than the
customer has accessed the customer’s account causing additional charges to
accrue or accessing personal identifying information; or
      (6)   Take other appropriate action to prevent or mitigate identity
theft.
   (B)   (1)   In the event that any town employee responsible for or involved
in opening a new covered account becomes aware of red flags indicating possible
identity theft with respect an application for a new account, such employee
shall use his or her discretion to determine whether such red flag or
combination of red flags suggests a threat of identity theft.
      (2)   If, in his or her discretion, such employee determines that
identity theft or attempted identity theft is likely or probable, such employee
shall immediately report such red flags to Council. If, in its discretion, such
employee deems that identity theft is unlikely or that reliable information is
available to reconcile red flags, the employee shall convey this information to
Council, who may in his or her discretion determine that no further action is
necessary.
      (3)   If in its discretion determines that further action is necessary, a
town employee shall perform one or more of the following responses, as
determined to be appropriate by Council:
         (a)   Request additional identifying information from the applicant;
         (b)   Deny the application for the new account;
         (c)   Notify law enforcement of possible identity theft; or
         (d)   Take other appropriate action to prevent or mitigate identity
theft.
(Ord. passed 9-9-2010)
§ 36.054 UPDATING THE PROGRAM.
   (A)   The Town Council (or board as the case may be) shall annually review
and, as deemed necessary by the Council, update the identity theft prevention
program along with any relevant red flags in order to reflect changes in risks
to customers or to the safety and soundness of the town and its covered
accounts from identity theft.
   (B)   In so doing, the Town Council shall consider the following factors and
exercise its discretion in amending the program:
      (1)   The city’s experiences with identity theft;
      (2)   Updates in methods of identity theft;
      (3)   Updates in customary methods used to detect, prevent and mitigate
identity theft;
      (4)   Updates in the types of accounts that the town offers or maintains;
and
      (5)   Updates in service provider arrangements.
(Ord. passed 9-9-2010)
§ 36.055 PROGRAM ADMINISTRATION.
   (A)   The Treasurer is responsible for oversight of the program and for
program implementation. The Council is responsible for reviewing reports
prepared by staff regarding compliance with red flag requirements and with
recommending material changes to the program, as necessary in the opinion of
the Council to address changing identity theft risks and to identify new or
discontinued types of covered accounts.
   (B)   Any recommended material changes to the program shall be submitted to
the Town Council for consideration by the Council.
      (1)   The Treasurer will report to the Council at least annually, on
compliance with the red flag requirements. The report will address material
matters related to the program and evaluate issues such as:
         (a)   The effectiveness of the policies and procedures of town in
addressing the risk of identity theft in connection with the opening of covered
accounts and with respect to existing covered accounts;
         (b)   Service provider arrangements;
         (c)   Significant incidents involving identity theft and management’s
response; and
         (d)   Recommendations for material changes to the program.
   (B)   The Treasurer is responsible for providing training to all employees
responsible for or involved in opening a new covered account, restoring an
existing covered account or accepting payment for a covered account with
respect to the implementation and requirements of the identity theft prevention
program. The Treasurer shall exercise his or her discretion in determining the
amount and substance of training necessary.
(Ord. passed 9-9-2010)
§ 36.056 OUTSIDE SERVICE PROVIDERS.
   In the event that the town engages a service provider to perform an activity
in connection with one or more covered accounts the Treasurer shall exercise
his or her discretion in reviewing such arrangements in order to ensure, to the
best of his or her ability, that the service provider’s activities are
conducted in accordance with policies and procedures, agreed upon by contract,
that are designed to detect any red flags that may arise in the performance of
the service provider’s activities and take appropriate steps to prevent or
mitigate identity theft.
(Ord. passed 9-9-2010)
§ 36.057 TREATMENT OF ADDRESS DISCREPANCIES.
   (A)   Short title. This section shall be known as the treatment of address
discrepancies.
   (B)   Purpose. Pursuant to 16 C.F.R. § 681.1, the purpose of this section is
to establish a process by which the town will be able to form a reasonable
belief that a consumer report relates to the consumer about whom it has
requested a consumer credit report when the town has received a notice of
address discrepancy.
   (C)   Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.
      NOTICE OF ADDRESS DISCREPANCY. Notice sent to a user by a consumer
reporting agency pursuant to 15 U.S.C. § 1681(c)(h)(l), that informs the user
of a substantial difference between the address for the consumer that the user
provided to request the consumer report and the address(es) in the agency’s
file for the consumer. See 16 C.F.R. § 681.1(b).
      TOWN. The Town of Oceana.
   (D)   Policy. In the event that the town receives a notice of address
discrepancy, the town employee responsible for verifying consumer addresses for
the purpose of providing the municipal service or account sought by the
consumer shall perform one or more of the following activities, as determined
to be appropriate by such employee:
      (1)   Compare the information in the consumer report with:
         (a)   Information the town obtains and uses to verify a consumer’s
identity in accordance with the requirements of the customer information
program rules implementing 31 U.S.C. § 5318(1);
         (b)   Information the town maintains in its own records, such as
applications for service, change of address notices, other customer account
records or tax records; or
         (c)   Information the town obtains from third-party sources that are
deemed reliable by the relevant town employee.
      (2)   Verify the information in the consumer report with the consumer.
   (E)   Furnishing consumer’s address to consumer reporting agency.
      (1)   In the event that the town reasonably confirms that an address
provided by a consumer to the town is accurate, the town is required to provide
such address to the consumer reporting agency from which the town received a
notice of address discrepancy with respect to such consumer. This information
is required to be provided to the consumer reporting agency when:
         (a)   The town is able to form a reasonable belief that the consumer
report relates to the consumer about whom the town requested the report;
         (b)   The town establishes a continuing relation with the consumer;
and
         (c)   The town regularly and in the ordinary course of business
provides information to the consumer reporting agency from which it received
the notice of address discrepancy.
      (2)   Such information shall be provided to the consumer reporting agency
as part of the information regularly provided by the town to such agency for
the reporting period in which the town establishes a relationship with the
customer.
   (F)   Methods of confirming consumer addresses. The town employee charged
with confirming consumer addresses may, in his or her discretion, confirm the
accuracy of an address through one or more of the following methods:
      (1)   Verifying the address with the consumer;
      (2)   Reviewing the city’s records to verify the consumer’s address;
      (3)   Verifying the address through third party sources; or
      (4)   Using other reasonable processes.
(Ord. passed 9-9-2010)
FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT REQUESTS
§ 36.070 SHORT TITLE.
   This subchapter shall be known and may be cited as the “FOIA Response
Ordinance”.
(Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 36.071 PURPOSES AND FINDINGS.
   The Town Council has determined that there needs to be a procedure followed
by the town when a FOIA request is received by the town, whether received by
the Treasurer, the Attorney or by any other town official or employee.
(Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 36.072 DETERMINATIONS.
   The Town Council hereby implements the following procedures for response to
a FOIA request.
   (A)   At all times the West Virginia State Code FOIA statutes will be
followed by the town.
   (B)   All speed will be exerted by all town officials and employees to see
that the FOIA statutes of the state are not violated.
   (C)   A FOIA request form will be given by the Treasurer to all individuals
who submit a verbal or written request, except in some cases, where the request
is made by an attorney on behalf of a client and the town has already received
a written request.
   (D)   A FOIA investigation form will be sent by the attorney for the town to
all elected town officials and to every employee who might have information
regarding a particular FOIA request.
   (E)   All town officials and employees agree to give any and all information
and/or documents to the attorney in a timely manner for the FOIA response so
that the attorney can determine what should be exempted from the FOIA request
and what should be sent to fulfill the request.
   (F)   The Attorney must work to fulfill all statutory deadlines as well and
complete the FOIA requests to the best of his or her ability.
   (G)   All town employees and officials agree to sign all internal documents
for the purpose of documentation of the city’s and the attorney’s files.
(Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 36.073 VIOLATIONS.
   Any employee who does not comply with a FOIA request or any internal
requests or does not respond in a timely manner is subject to disciplinary
procedures from the Town of Oceana Employee Handbook.
(Ord. passed 7-12-2012)
§ 36.074 RATES.
   (A)   Short title. This section shall be known and may be cited as the “FOIA
Rate Ordinance”.
   (B)   Purposes and findings. The Town Council has determined that there
needs to be certain monetary rates followed by the town when a FOIA request is
received by the town.
   (C)   Determinations. The Town Council hereby implements the following
expense schedule for response to a FOIA request.
      (1)   Any person, corporation or other entity must pay $1 per page of
information requested.
      (2)   Any person, corporation or other entity must pay $5 per video
requested.
   (D)   Violations. Any employee who does not enforce this rate schedule for a
FOIA request is subject to disciplinary procedures from the Town of Oceana
Employee Handbook.
(Ord. passed 2-12-2015)

MUNICIPAL COURT
§ 37.01 MUNICIPAL COURT CREATED; PRESIDING JUDGE.
   (A)   There is hereby created the Municipal Court of the town, which shall
be presided over by the Municipal Court Judge.
   (B)   The Municipal Court Judge shall be appointed by the Council by a
majority vote of the members thereof and shall serve as such municipal judge
for a period of two years, his or her term of office commencing on July 1 and
continuing for a period of one year. There shall be no limit as the number of
terms a judge may serve.
   (C)   The municipal judge shall receive such compensation as fixed for the
judge by the Council.
   (D)   The Council may, at its discretion, appoint an alternate judge,
compensation for which shall be as fixed by the Council.
   (E)   In the absence of the municipal judge, the alternate judge shall
preside.
   (F)   The municipal judge shall attend and complete the next available
course of instruction in rudimentary principals of law once appointed unless he
or she has been admitted to practice law in this state.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2011)
§ 37.02 JUDGE; BOND.
   No person shall exercise any power or perform any duty as Municipal Court
Judge until he or she has qualified for such office by giving such faithful
performance and true accounting bond as may be required by the Town Council,
under which he or she shall be responsible for all town funds coming into his
or her hands by virtue of his or her office.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2011)
§ 37.03 JUDGE; POWERS AND DUTIES GENERALLY.
   (A)   The Municipal Court Judge shall be a conservator of the peace within
the town and, insofar as any ordinance of the town is concerned, shall have and
exercise all such powers and duties in criminal cases as does a magistrate in
any lawful exercise under the statutes of the state; and he or she shall also
be, ex officio, a magistrate within the town and shall, within the town, have
and exercise all the powers relating to crime and perform all duties fixed by
law upon a magistrate; except, that he or she shall have no jurisdiction over
civil cases.
   (B)   The Municipal Court Judge shall have further powers and perform such
other duties as may be, from time to time, prescribed or conferred by any law
of the state or by ordinance of the town, as well as the judicial powers
conferred upon the Mayor, insofar as such provisions are not in conflict with
the state Constitution or any state statute which takes precedence.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2011)
§ 37.04 DOCKET; ALLOCATION OF FEES, FINES AND COSTS.
   (A)   There shall be a docket of the Municipal Court, and it shall be the
duty of the municipal judge to docket fully thereon all cases in the Court, and
show therein all fees, fines and costs adjudged and collected.
   (B)   The Municipal Court Judge shall, at least once a month, make a written
report to the Town Council and Treasurer, showing a total of all receipts for
the previous month.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2011)
§ 37.05 RECORD OF TRAFFIC CASES; TRAFFIC VIOLATIONS BUREAU.
   The Municipal Court Judge shall keep or cause to be kept a record of every
traffic complaint and other legal form of traffic charge deposited with or
presented to the Municipal Court of its Traffic Violations Bureau, if and when
such bureau is established, and shall keep a record of every official action by
the Court or its Traffic Violations Bureau in reference thereto, including, but
not limited, to a record of every conviction, forfeiture of bail, judgment or
acquittal, and the amount of fine or forfeiture resulting from every traffic
complaint deposited with or presented to the Court of Traffic Violations
Bureau.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2011)
Cross-reference:
   Traffic code enforcement, see §§
70.15 to
70.22
   Traffic control; conformity with State Manual, see §
70.36
§ 37.06 APPEALS; MINIMUM FINE.
   (A)   (1)   Every person sentenced by the municipal judge to imprisonment or
to the payment of a fine of $10 or more shall be allowed an appeal to the
Circuit Court of the county; the procedure upon appeal from the Municipal Court
shall be the same as that for an appeal from a Magistrate’s Court.
      (2)   The defendant has 20 days from sentencing to appeal the ruling to a
higher court. It is the responsibility of the defendant or the defendant’s
attorney to notify the Municipal Court of the Appeal.
      (3)   The presiding Municipal Judge may place the defendant on an appeal
bond upon notification of the appeal to a higher court.
   (B)   In no case shall a fine of less than $10 be imposed if a defendant,
his or her agent or attorney objects thereto.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2011)
§ 37.07 ENFORCEMENT AND COLLECTION OF FINES, COSTS AND FEES.
   Upon failure to pay any fine or costs adjudged against him or her, the
municipal judge may be authorized to suspend the driving privileges of the
defendant until all fines or costs have been satisfied. In addition, the
municipal judge shall have the same authority and power in collection of fines,
fees and costs as are given to a magistrate under the laws of the state.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2011)
§ 37.08 COSTS GENERALLY.
   (A)   The town shall be entitled to and the municipal judge may collect on
behalf of the town, in all cases appearing before him or her involving
violations of the town ordinances, the same costs, fees and allowances, and in
the same amounts as a magistrate may collect, according to state law.
   (B)   Neither the Mayor, municipal judge, Recorder, any police officer, nor
any other person shall be entitled to or receive any fee for any services
rendered in or about any trial or other proceeding before the Municipal Court
of the town.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2011)
§ 37.09 PERSONS AUTHORIZED TO ISSUE WARRANTS FOR OFFENSES.
   The municipal judge shall have the authority to issue warrants for all
offenses committed within the police jurisdiction of the town.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2011)
§ 37.10 CONTINUATION OF PREVIOUS ACTION.
   Any previous action of Council relating to the establishment or function of
a Municipal Court, are continued in effect and shall be exercised by the
Municipal Court, except however, those which are in conflict with this chapter
or in conflict with the laws of the state.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2011)
§ 37.11 PROVISIONS SEVERABLE.
   The provisions of this chapter shall be construed as severable and should
any section or part thereof be held unconstitutional or for any reason invalid
or unenforceable by a court of competent jurisdiction, the unaffected portions
shall remain valid and shall give full force and effect.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2011)
§ 37.12 JURY TRIAL.
   (A)   Only a defendant who has been charged with an offense for which a
period of confinement in jail may be imposed is entitled to a trial by jury. If
a Municipal Court Judge determines, upon demand of a defendant, to conduct a
trial by jury in a criminal manner, it shall follow the procedures set forth in
the rules of criminal procedures for magistrate courts promulgated by the
Supreme Court of Appeals, except that the jury in a Municipal Court shall
consist of 12 members.
   (B)   Any time a trial by jury is granted by the Municipal Court Judge, the
defendant shall be responsible for the payment of the juror’s fees of $10 per
day of service for each juror to the Clerk of the Court for disbursement to
each juror. Also the defendant shall pay the Clerk a sum of $200 for
administrative fees (mailings, notices and costs associated) for the trial.
These fees and costs are passed to the defendant, only if the defendant is
found guilty.
   (C)   The jury pool for Municipal Court shall be comprised of the voting
population with the municipal limits of the town.
   (D)   The Municipal Court Judge shall appoint two commissioners of the jury
upon notification of the need for a jury trial. The jury commissioners shall be
responsible for obtaining the current voters listed for the municipality from
the County Clerk’s office. After receipts of the voters lists from the county,
the jury commissioners will assemble jury tabs to be deposited in a secure
locked box from which the draft of jurors will be selected.
   (E)   Two weeks before the date of the trial, the commissioners will select
30 names from the locked box. The commissioners will then forward a letter
detailing the need for a jury for a Municipal Court trial and the date, time
and location for the potential jurors to appear.
   (F)   When the jurors appear, the prosecuting attorney and defense attorney
(or defendant) will have the potential to strike down to 14 persons. Twelve
persons will serve as jurors and two will serve as alternates.
   (G)   Instructions to juries will be handed down from the Municipal Court
Judge at the time of the trial. Appeals from jury trials will be handled in the
same manner as any other appeal. They are appealed to the Circuit Court of the
county.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2011)
§ 37.13 FAILURE TO APPEAR FOR SUMMONS, WARRANT OR CITATION.
   (A)   If, having been notified at the time of issuance of a citation, by any
officer of the municipal Police Department a defendant fails to appear within a
given time period, he or she shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and assessed
fines and costs not more that $1,000 and/or up to 30 days in jail time in the
Southern Regional Jail.
   (B)   If a defendant fails to respond or appear for a summons or warrant
issued by the Municipal Court Judge, he or she shall be found guilty of a
misdemeanor and assessed fines and costs of not more than $1,000 and/or up to
30 days jail time in the Southern Regional Jail.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2011)
§ 37.14 COMMUNITY SERVICE WORK SUBSTITUTED IN LIEU OF FINE.
   (A)   Notwithstanding any provision of this code to the contrary, a
municipal judge may substitute, in lieu of the imposition of a sentence of
incarceration or imposition of a fine, community service work for such
incarceration or fine. Where community service work is ordered as a substitute
on a sentence of incarceration, an eight-hour work day shall extinguish one day
of any sentence of incarceration. The minimum wage in effect at the time
sentencing is imposed shall be used to compute the amount of community service
work necessary to extinguish the fine. At the discretion of the Court, the
sentence credits may run concurrently or consecutively.
   (B)   Any community service ordered pursuant to the provisions of this
section shall be performed for government entities or charitable or nonprofit
entities and be supervised by the Chief of Police of the municipality or his or
her designee.
   (C)   Persons sentenced under the provisions of this section remain under
the jurisdiction of the Municipal Court. The Court may withdraw the community
service sentence at anytime by order entered with or without notice and order a
person previously sentenced to community service to serve the term of
incarceration or to pay the fine available to the Court upon the person’s
conviction; provided, that any community service work performed before the
community service sentence is withdrawn shall be credited against any term of
incarceration or fine imposed.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2011)
§ 37.15 FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH COURT ORDERED SENTENCING AND CONTEMPT.
   (A)   If any defendant, who has been ordered by the Court to comply with
sentencing, fails to comply with any terms of said sentence, they are guilty of
a misdemeanor and shall be fined not less that $50 nor more that $1,000 and/or
confined to the Southern Regional Jail for not more that 30 days.
   (B)   The Court and the judge thereof may issue an attachment for contempt
and punish them summarily. The Court shall not impose a monetary fine of more
than $50 or imprison more than ten days for each charge of contempt. No Court
shall impose a fine for contempt unless the defendant be present in Court, or
shall have been served with a rule of the Court to show cause, on some certain
day, and shall have failed to appear and show cause.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2011)
§ 37.16 PROBATION.
   (A)   The Municipal Court Judge may consider placing a defendant on
probation as prescribed by the rules and regulations of Magistrate Court
proceedings in the state. If the defendant fails to comply with the terms of
probation specified at the time of sentencing, he or she will be in violation
of court ordered sentencing-probation. The prosecuting attorney of this
municipality will file the charge of violation of probation.
   (B)   (1)   Once the charge has been filed, a hearing for revocation of the
probation will be held.
      (2)   If, after the hearing, the defendant is found to be in violation of
his or her probation, the municipal judge may make alterations to the
probation, revoke the probation, and/or sentence in accord with the provisions
of this chapter.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2011)
§ 37.17 ALTERNATIVE SENTENCING.
   (A)   This Municipal Court and its officers have the same authority as the
magistrate courts of the state to utilize alternative sentencing programs.
Programs such as day report, home confinement, community service or pre-
judgment alternative disposition may be imposed as part of a plea agreement,
sentencing, probation or bond.
   (B)   The sentencing is the decision of the municipal judge and may be
supervised by a County Sheriff or Day Report Supervisor in other than the
county in which the defendant resides.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2011)
§ 37.18 COURT REIMBURSEMENT.
   (A)   All charges brought before the Municipal Court that carry
incarceration as a penalty shall result in a remittance to the regional jail
authority of a flat rate of $40 and a $2 flat rate remitted to the General Fund
of the town for processing.
   (B)   All charges bought before the Municipal Court will reflect the
following costs remitted to the State Treasurer’s office:
 
Community Corrections Fee       $10
Crime Victims Reparations Fund  $8
Driving Under the Influence Fee $55 and 20% of DUI fine assessed
Law Enforcement Training Fund   $2
 
   (C)   All charges brought before the Municipal Court will reflect the
following costs remitted to the General Fund for the town for an administrative
fee for court of $20.
   (D)   The above noted are to be added to all cases, as applicable, and
hereby known as “court costs”. They are in addition to any fines and penalties
in accordance with the Municipal Court and are effective at the date of
passage.
(Ord. passed 1-13-2011)
