CHAPTER 50: GENERAL PROVISIONS
Section
   
50.01   Illegal or fraudulent procurement of water, gas or electric
   
50.02   Tampering with and theft of utilities
 
   
50.99   Penalty
§ 50.01 ILLEGAL OR FRAUDULENT PROCUREMENT OF WATER, GAS OR ELECTRIC.
   Every person who, with intent to injure or defraud, procures, makes or
causes to be made, any pipe, tube, wire or other conductor of gas, water or
electric energy, and connects the same, or causes it to be connected, with any
main, service pipe or other pipe for conducting or supplying gas, or water, or
any wires or other conductor of electric energy, in such manner as to supply
gas, water or electric energy to any lamp, motor, burner, orifice or any other
device, by or at which gas, water or electric energy is consumed, around or
without passing through the meter provided for measuring and registering the
quantity of gas, water or electric energy consumed, or in any other manner so
as to evade payment therefore, and every person who, with like intent, injures
or alters any gas, water or electric meter, or obstructs its action, shall be
in violation of this section.
(Ord. passed 5-12-2016; Ord. passed 4-13-2017) Penalty, see §
50.99
§ 50.02 TAMPERING WITH AND THEFT OF UTILITIES.
   (A)   Short title. This section shall be known and may be cited as the
“Tampering with and Theft of Utilities Ordinance”.
   (B)   Purposes and findings. The Town Council has determined that it is
necessary for it to adopt the state code regarding the theft and tampering with
utilities within its jurisdiction.
   (C)   Definitions. For purposes of this section, the following terms,
phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given within the
West Virginia Code. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the
present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the
singular and words in the singular number include the plural.
      TOWN. The Town of Oceana, West Virginia with administrative offices
located on Route 10, Cook Parkway, P.O. Box 190, Oceana, West Virginia 24870.
   (D)   Incorporation of state law.
      (1)   Every person who, with intent to injure or defraud, procures, makes
or causes to be made, any pipe, tube, wire or other conductor of gas, water or
electric energy, and connects the same, or causes it to be connected, with any
main, service pipe or other pipe for conducting or supplying gas, or water, or
any wires or other conductor of electric energy, in such manner as to supply
gas, water or electric energy to any lamp, motor, burner, orifice or any other
device, by or at which gas, water or electric energy is consumed, around or
without passing through the meter provided for measuring and registering the
quantity of gas, water or electric energy consumed, or in any other manner so
as to evade payment therefor, and every person who, with like intent, injures
or alters any gas, water or electric meter, or obstructs its action, shall be
in violation of this section.
      (2)   Every person who, with intent to injure or defraud, connects, or
causes to be connected, any pipe, tube, wire, electrical conductor or other
instrument with any main, service pipe, or other pipe or conduit or flume for
conducting water, or with any main, service pipe or other pipe or conduit for
conducting gas, or with any main, service wire or other electric conductor used
for the purpose of conducting electric energy for light, heat or motive
services, for the purpose of taking therefrom water, gas or electric energy,
without the knowledge of the owner thereof and with intent to evade payment
therefor, shall be in violation of this section.
(Ord. passed 6-8-2006) Penalty, see §
50.99
§ 50.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter, for which no other
penalty is provided, shall be subject to the penalty provisions of §
10.99.
   (B)   Any person who violates §
50.01 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and, upon conviction thereof, shall be
penalized. The amounts and/or jail time are as follows:
 
First offense  $250 fine and/or 10 days in jail
Second offense $500 fine and/or 15 days in jail
Third offense  $750 fine and/or 30 days in jail
 
   (C)   (1)   Any person who violates §
50.02(D)(1) shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and, upon conviction thereof,
shall be confined in the county jail not exceeding 12 months, or fined not
exceeding $1,000, or both, in the discretion of the court,
      (2)   Any person who violates §
50.02(D)(2) shall be guilty a misdemeanor; and, upon conviction thereof, shall
be confined in the county jail not exceeding 12 months, or fined not exceeding
$1,000, or both, in the discretion of the court.
(Ord. passed 6-8-2006; Ord. passed 5-12-2016; Ord. passed 4-13-2017)
CHAPTER 51: REFUSE AND GARBAGE
Section
   
51.01   Authority
   
51.02   Findings and determination
   
51.03   Definitions
   
51.04   Unlawful activities
   
51.05   Residential requirements
   
51.06   Residential fees, charges, procedures for collection and remedies for
nonpayment
   
51.07   Commercial requirements
   
51.08   Commercial fees, charges, procedures for collection and remedies for
nonpayment
   
51.09   Power of Council Chairperson of Garbage Department
 
   
51.99   Penalty
§ 51.01 AUTHORITY.
   This chapter is adopted pursuant to the provisions of W. Va. Code § 8-12-
5 and W. Va. Code §§ 8-11-1 et seq., and amendments thereto, and other
applicable provisions of law.
(Ord. passed 8-14-2014)
§ 51.02 FINDINGS AND DETERMINATION.
   It is hereby found, determined and declared as follows. The ordinance
heretofore adopted by the Town Council on May 1, 1955, and amendments thereto,
regulating and providing for refuse collection in the town, are considered and
deemed in variance with the present policies of the Public Service Commission
of the state regarding refuse collection, and in compliance therewith it is
necessary and requisite to amended said ordinance.
(Ord. passed 8-14-2014)
§ 51.03 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   PERSON. Any individual, partnership, firm or corporation.
   PRIVATE SCAVENGER. One who for hire, or otherwise, collects, removes or
disposes of refuse.
   REFUSE. All sweepings, cleanings, trash, rubbish, litter, garbage industrial
or domestic wastes; organic wastes or residue of animals sold as meat, fruit or
other vegetables, or other vegetable matter from kitchens, dining rooms,
markets or places dealing in or handling meats, fowls, fruits, grains or
vegetables; offal, animal excretia, the carcasses of animals, tree or shrub
trimmings, grass clippings, dirt, wood, stone, brick, plastic, or materials
resulting from the demolition, alteration or construction of buildings or
structures, accumulated waste materials or substance which may become
nuisances, including waste material from kitchens, dining rooms and similar
places, whether the liquids have been drained from the same or not; swill, and
ashes, residue resulting from the combustion of coals, coke or wood, in
domestic, industrial or commercial stoves, furnaces or boilers.
   REFUSE DISPOSAL. The disposition of refuse in accordance with rules and
regulations promulgated by the Town Council.
   REFUSE COLLECTIONS. The gathering of refuse containers and their contents
from the premises of improved property and loading contents into removal
vehicles, and returning containers to place where found after contents have
been emptied, for which the charge is made, as provided for in §
51.04(A).
   REFUSE CONTAINERS.
      (1)   A standard container, to be furnished by the user of this garbage
and trash service, which shall be substantially made of metal, to be leak;
proof and water-tight with a tight-fitting metal cover.
      (2)   The Town Council or other proper officer of the trash and garbage
collection service may authorize or direct the use of such other or special
containers as the circumstances of any particular situation may require.
   REFUSE REMOVAL. The hauling and transportation of refuse from point of
collection to point of disposal.
(Ord. passed 8-14-2014)
§ 51.04 UNLAWFUL ACTIVITIES.
   (A)   (1)   It will be unlawful for any person, except the town, to engage
in or conduct the business of collection, removal or disposal of refuse, within
the municipal limits of the town, and all persons, business houses, firms or
corporations residing in or doing business within the town shall be required to
subscribe to, take and pay for the service provided by trash and garbage
collection service of the town.
      (2)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to neglect
or fail to subscribe to such service and to pay for the same at rates
established by the Town Council for the type of service furnished each such
person, firm or corporation.
   (B)   On and after the date when this chapter becomes operative, there shall
be a trash and garbage collection service under the supervision and direction
of the Town Council. This trash and garbage collection service shall be
adequately equipped and supplied with personnel and equipment to properly and
satisfactorily carry out the essential public service of collection, removal
and disposal of refuse produced in the households and places of business of the
citizens of the town. The trash and garbage collection service supervisor, with
the approval of the Council, shall have, and is hereby given, authority to
prescribe, publish, promulgate and enforce any and all reasonable rules and
regulations deemed by him or her necessary or proper, consistent with this
ordinance, to carry out the objects and purposes thereof and for the safety and
health of the citizens of the town in respect to the collection, removal or
disposal of refuse as herein defined.
   (C)   Private scavengers, push cart operators and private garbage collectors
are hereby prohibited from engaging in the business of transporting or
disposing of trash and refuse.
   (D)   Persons and firms are hereby prohibited from transporting thereover
trash and refuse along the public streets and alleys of the town for disposal
within or without the town, without first obtaining permission from the
supervisor of the trash and garbage collection service or from the Town
Council.
(Ord. passed 8-14-2014) Penalty, see §
51.99
§ 51.05 RESIDENTIAL REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   (1)   All persons, business houses, firms or corporations residing in
or doing business within the corporate limits of the town shall be required to
pay the trash and garbage fee of the town.
      (2)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to
neglect, refuse or fail to pay for the same at rates established by the Town
Council for the type of service for each such person, firm or corporation.
   (B)   Private scavengers, push cart operators and private garbage collectors
are hereby prohibited from engaging in the business of transporting or
disposing of trash and refuse.
   (C)   Persons and firms are hereby prohibited from transporting thereover
trash and refuse along the public streets and alleys of the town for disposal
within or without the town, without first obtaining permission from the
supervisor of the trash and garbage collection service or from the Town Council
are hereby ordered deleted.
(Ord. passed 8-14-2014) Penalty, see §
51.99
§ 51.06 RESIDENTIAL FEES, CHARGES, PROCEDURES FOR COLLECTION AND REMEDIES FOR
NONPAYMENT.
   (A)   In order to provide this trash and garbage collection service for the
town, on a self-supporting basis, and to finance the operation thereof, there
shall be, and there is hereby, established a schedule of fees, rates and
charges for standard types of refuse, garbage and sanitation service within the
town as follows: Class 1, Residential, minimum charge for standard monthly
service is increased from $15 per month to $19 per month.
   (B)   Under these schedules the town shall not collect, remove or dispose of
the following types of refuse: offal; sewage; animal excretia; the carcasses of
animals, tree or shrub trimmings; or material resulting from the demolition,
repair, alteration or erection, of buildings or structures.
   (C)   If the fee, rate or charges for any of the foregoing services, shall
not be paid within 30 days after the same is due, the amount thereof may be
recovered by the town in any appropriate action in accordance with the laws of
the state. Upon the failure of any person receiving such service to pay for the
same when due, the town may discontinue such service without notice.
   (D)   The town shall have the right to deny standard refuse service, to any
person whose refuse requirements are sufficiently abnormal or different, in the
opinion of the Council, as to justify special handling in which case a special
charge will be made. This shall include those buildings or dwellings not
readily accessible to refuse collectors, or in cases where refuse is not found
in standard containers.
   (E)   (1)   The Town Treasurer’s office shall be in charge of collections of
fees and charges due, and to become due, to the town from the users of this
trash and garbage collection service. Said Town Treasurer’s office shall keep
in his or her office proper records showing all collections made and received
by him or her and shall prepare and deliver to the Town Council each month, or
sooner if requested a detailed statement, in writing, setting out moneys
received for all services during the immediately proceeding period, and show by
names and in other details the persons and firms who have not paid.
      (2)   The Town Council shall prescribe such forms and records as shall be
proper and necessary for the collection and accounting of all moneys for any
and all services under this chapter, the system of accounting prescribed by the
Town Council shall show the amount of revenue received and the application of
the same, and the Mayor shall, at least once a year, cause such accounts to be
properly audited by a competent auditor, and the report of auditor shall be
open for inspection at all times to any taxpayer or citizen of the town, or any
person receiving service under the provisions of this chapter.
   (F)   (1)   The entire gross revenue derived from the charges mentioned in
this section shall be placed to the credit of a fund and deposited to the
credit of a special account in any duly qualified town depository, to be known
as the town’s Garbage Fund.
      (2)   Also in the annual budget of the town the items of receipts and
disbursements of this trash and garbage collection service shall be set out
separate and apart from those of any other department or service.
   (G)   The Town Council shall have the right to revise the foregoing schedule
of rates and so adjust them that costs will be distributed as equitably as
possible among all citizens of the town on the basis of benefits received. At
no time however, shall rates be continued which are disclosed to be producing
less revenue than is required to meet all obligations and costs involved in
rendering refuse service to the public.
   (H)   It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or to permit the
accumulation of refuse in, about or upon premises owned, occupied or used by
them, when and if, in the judgment of the Town Council, such accumulation is
unsightly, unsanitary or hazardous to the property, life, health, safety or
welfare of the people.
   (I)   It shall be unlawful to deliver refuse in or upon private property.
   (J)   It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, place or scatter any
garbage, rubbish, trash, ashes or other refuse over or upon any premises,
street or alley, either public or private, or adjacent thereto, and either with
or without the intent to later remove or burn, or to suffer or permit from the
accumulation of refuse, any premises owned, occupied or controlled by such
persons, to become or remain offensive, unsanitary, unsightly, unsafe to public
health or hazardous from fire.
   (K)   It shall be unlawful for any person to store or permit to be stored,
refuse on or about their premises, or the premises occupied by them, unless
such refuse is kept separately in standard trash and garbage containers as
defined in this chapter.
   (L)   All persons, firms, and corporations using the essential service or
services provided for in this chapter within the municipal limits of the town
shall be required to make all refuse containers available on the ground floor
and accessible to the collectors anytime on the scheduled day of collection for
the particular area in which such users reside. It shall be the duty of all
users of such service to ascertain the collection schedules for the area in
which they reside. If any such user or users shall fail to make their refuse
containers available as herein required the collectors shall refuse to make
such collection, and such refusal shall not constitute a failure of collection.
(Ord. passed 8-14-2014) Penalty, see §
51.99
§ 51.07 COMMERCIAL REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   (1)   All persons, business houses, firms or corporations residing in
or doing business within the corporate limits of the town shall be required to
pay the trash and garbage fee of the town.
      (2)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to
neglect, refuse or fail to pay for the same at rates established by the Town
Council for the type of service for each such person, firm or corporation.
   (B)   Private scavengers, push cart operators and private garbage collectors
are hereby prohibited from engaging in the business of transporting or
disposing of trash and refuse.
(Ord. passed 8-14-2014) Penalty, see §
51.99
§ 51.08 COMMERCIAL FEES, CHARGES, PROCEDURES FOR COLLECTION AND REMEDIES FOR
NONPAYMENT.
   (A)   In order to provide this trash and garbage collection service for the
town on a self-supporting basis, and to finance the operation thereof, there
shall be, and there is hereby, established a schedule of fees, rates and
charges for standard types of refuse, garbage and sanitation service within the
town as follows:
Class Minimum Charge for Standard Monthly Services
Class               Minimum Charge for Standard Monthly Services
Class 2, Commercial $30 per month
Class 3, Commercial 2 yd. dumpster, $32 per month
Class 4, Commercial 3 yd. dumpster, $48 per month
Class 5, Commercial 4 yd. dumpster, $64 per month
Class 6, Commercial 6 yd. dumpster, $96 per month
Class 7, Commercial 8 yd. dumpster, $128 per month
Class 8, Commercial 10 yd. dumpster, $160 per month
Class 9, Commercial 12 yd. dumpster, $192 per month
 
   (B)   Under these schedules the town shall not collect, remove or dispose of
the following types of refuse: offal; sewage; animal excretia; the carcasses of
animals; tree or shrub trimmings; or material resulting from the demolition,
repair, alteration or erection, of buildings or structures.
   (C)   (1)   If the fee, rate or charges for any of the foregoing services,
shall not be paid within 30 days after the same is due, the amount thereof may
be recovered by the town in any appropriate action in accordance with the laws
of the state.
      (2)   Upon the failure of any person receiving such service to pay for
the same when due, the town may discontinue such service without notice.
   (D)   The town shall have the right to deny standard refuse service, to any
person whose refuse requirements are sufficiently abnormal or different, in the
opinion of the Council, as to justify special handling in which case a special
charge will be made. This shall include those buildings or dwellings not
readily accessible to refuse collectors, or in cases where refuse is not found
in standard containers.
   (E)   The Town Treasurer’s office shall be in charge of collections of fees
and charges due, and to become due, to the town from the users of this trash
and garbage collection service. Said Town Treasurer’s office shall keep in his
or her office proper records showing all collections made and received by him
or her and shall prepare and deliver to the Town Council each twenty-first day
of the month, or sooner if requested a detailed statement, in writing, setting
out moneys received for all sendees during the immediately proceeding period,
and show by names and in other details the persons and firms who have not paid.
The Town Council shall prescribe such forms and records as shall be proper and
necessary for the collection and accounting of all moneys for any and all
services under this chapter, the system of accounting prescribed by the Town
Council shall show the amount of revenue received and the application of the
same, and the Mayor shall, at least once a year, cause such accounts to be
properly audited by a competent auditor, and the report of auditor shall be
open for inspection at all times to any taxpayer or citizen of the town, or any
person receiving service under the provisions of this chapter.
   (F)   (1)   The entire gross revenue derived from the charges mentioned in
division (E) of this section shall be placed to the credit of a fund and
deposited to the credit of a special account in any duly qualified town
depository, to be known as the town’s Garbage Fund.
      (2)   Also in the annual budget of the town the items of receipts and
disbursements of this trash and garbage collection service shall be set out
separate and apart from those of any other department or service.
   (G)   The Town Council shall have the right to revise the foregoing schedule
of rates and so adjust them that costs will be distributed as equitably as
possible among all citizens of the town on the basis of benefits received. At
no time, however, shall rates be continued which are disclosed to be producing
less revenue than is required to meet all obligations and costs involved in
rendering refuse service to the public.
   (H)   It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or to permit the
accumulation of refuse in, about, or upon premises owned, occupied or used by
them, when and if, in the judgment of the Town Council, such accumulation is
unsightly, unsanitary or hazardous to the property, life, health, safety or
welfare of the people.
   (I)   It shall be unlawful to deliver refuse in or upon private property.
   (J)   It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, place or scatter any
garbage, rubbish, trash, ashes or other refuse over or upon any premises,
street or alley, either public or private, or adjacent thereto, and either with
or without the intent to later remove or burn, or to suffer or permit from the
accumulation of refuse, any premises owned, occupied or controlled by such
persons, to become or remain offensive, unsanitary, unsightly, unsafe to public
health or hazardous from fire.
   (K)   It shall be unlawful for any person to store or permit to be stored,
refuse on or about their premises, or the premises occupied by them, unless
such refuse is kept separately in standard trash and garbage containers as
defined in this chapter.
   (L)   All persons, firms and corporations using the essential service or
services provided for in this chapter within the municipal limits of the town
shall be required to make all refuse containers available on the ground floor
and accessible to the collectors anytime on the scheduled day of collection for
the particular area in which such users reside. It shall be the duty of all
users of such service to ascertain the collection schedules for the area in
which they reside. If any such user or users shall fail to make their refuse
containers available as herein required, the collectors shall refuse to make
such collection, and such refusal shall not constitute a failure of collection.
(Ord. passed 8-14-2014)
§ 51.09 POWER OF COUNCIL CHAIRPERSON OF GARBAGE DEPARTMENT.
   The supervisor of the trash and garbage collection service of the town, with
the consent and approval, first obtained, of the Town Council, shall have the
right from time to time to establish, issue, revise, revoke and otherwise
promulgate such rules, regulations and procedures as may be necessary or proper
to carry out and fulfill the intent of the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. passed 8-14-2014)
§ 51.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Generally. Any person violating any provision of this chapter, for
which no other penalty is provided, shall be subject to the penalty provisions
of §
10.99.
   (B)   Residential fees, §
51.06. In addition to the discontinuation of services, the town may assess a
fine of $100, each successive week that the customer does not pay the garbage
fees to the town. Each succeeding week that a violation of §
51.06 exists shall constitute a new and separate offense.
   (C)   Commercial fees, §
51.08. In addition to the discontinuation of services, the town may assess a
fine of $100, each successive week that the customer does not pay the garbage
fees to the town. Each succeeding week that a violation of §
51.08 exists shall constitute a new and separate offense.
(Ord. passed 8-14-2014)
CHAPTER 52: CROSS-CONNECTION AND BACKFLOW PREVENTION PROGRAM
Section
   
52.01   Purpose
   
52.02   Authority
   
52.03   Responsibility
   
52.04   Definitions
   
52.05   Administration
   
52.06   Requirements
   
52.07   Degree of hazard
   
52.08   Existing in-use backflow prevention devices
   
52.09   Periodic testing
   
52.10   Records
§ 52.01 PURPOSE.
   (A)   Generally. The town recognizes that cross-connections and backflow
conditions either existing or potential in a public water system and/or a
customer’s water distribution system pose a threat to the public health and the
environment. Therefore, the following program and policy apply to the town’s
public water system (water purveyor) and to our customer’s water distribution
system/s/owner).
   (B)   Purpose.
      (1)   To protect the public water system served by the town from the
possibility of contamination or pollution by isolating within its customer’s
internal distribution water system(s), such contaminants or pollutants that
could backflow due to back-pressure or back-siphonage into the public water
system;
      (2)   To promote the elimination and/or control of cross-connections and
backflow conditions, actual or potential, within a customer’s internal
distribution water system(s), non-potable systems, plumbing fixtures and
processes; and
      (3)   To provide for the maintenance of a continuing program of cross-
connection and backflow prevention control which will effectively prevent the
contamination or pollution of the public and/or customer’s water system(s) from
cross-connections and backflow conditions.
(Ord. passed 10-28-2004)
§ 52.02 AUTHORITY.
   By the Federal Safe Drinking Water Act of 1974 and 1996 amendment, being 42
U.S.C. §§ 300f et seq., and W. Va. Code Chapter 16, Article 1 and public health
laws, state’s Bureau for Public Health Chapter 1, Article 5B, the water
purveyor has the primary responsibility for preventing water from unapproved
sources, or any other substances, from entering the public potable water
system.
(Ord. passed 10-28-2004)
§ 52.03 RESPONSIBILITY.
   The water purveyor shall be responsible for the protection of the public
potable water distribution system from contamination or pollution due to
backflow from back-pressure or back-siphonage of contaminants or pollutants
through the water service connection. If, in the judgement of the water
purveyor, an approved backflow preventer assembly is required at the water
service connection to any customer’s premises, the water purveyor, or his or
her delegated agent, shall give notice in writing to said customer to install
an approved backflow preventer assembly at each service connection to his or
her premises. The customer shall, within 90 days, install such approved
assembly, or assemblies, at his or her own expense, and failure or refusal, or
inability on the part of the customer to install said assembly or assemblies
within 90 days, shall constitute a grounds for discontinuing water service to
the premises until such assembly or assemblies have been properly installed.
(Ord. passed 10-28-2004)
§ 52.04 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   APPROVED. Accepted by the water purveyor as meeting an applicable
specification stated or cited in the state’s Department of Health and Human
Resources regulation, or as suitable for the proposed purpose.
   ASSEMBLY. A backflow preventer usually consisting of a combination of
approved check valve components and additional instrumentation including
approved shutoff valves and test cocks.
   AUXILIARY WATER SUPPLY. Any water supply or water source, on or available,
to a customer’s premises other than the water purveyor’s approved public water
system,
   BACKFLOW. The undesirable reversal of water flow or introduction of other
liquids, mixtures or substances, caused by a pressure differential in the
distribution pipes of a potable water system.
   BACKFLOW CONDITION(S). Any set of circumstances, actual or potential that
could be construed to create a cross-connection allowing for backflow of a
contaminant or pollutant to enter a potable water system.
   BACKFLOW PREVENTER. A device or assembly, or means designed to prevent
backflow in a potable water system. Most commonly categorized as air gap,
atmospheric vacuum breaker, barometric loop, double check with intermediate
atmospheric vent, double check valve assembly, hose bibb vacuum breaker,
pressure vacuum breaker, reduced pressure principle assembly and residential
dual check.
      (1)   AIR GAP. A physical separation sufficient to prevent backflow
between the free-flowing discharge end of the potable water system and any
other system. Physically defined as a distance equal to twice the diameter of
the supply side pipe diameter but never less than one inch.
      (2)   ATMOSPHERIC VACUUM BREAKER. A device which prevents backflow by
creating an atmospheric vent when there is either a negative pressure or sub-
atmospheric pressure in a water system.
      (3)   BAROMETRIC LOOP. A fabricated piping arrangement rising at least 35
feet at its topmost point above the highest fixture it supplies. It is utilized
in water supply systems to protect against back-siphonage.
      (4)   DOUBLE CHECK VALVE ASSEMBLY. An assembly of two independently
operating spring loaded check valves with tightly closing shutoff valve on each
side of the check valves, and property located test cocks for the testing of
each check valve.
      (5)   DOUBLE CHECK VALVE WITH INTERMEDIATE ATMOSPHERIC VENT. A device
having two spring loaded check valves separated by an atmospheric vent chamber.
      (6)   HOSE BIBB VACUUM BREAKER. A device attached to a hose bibb and
which acts as an atmospheric vacuum breaker.
      (7)   PRESSURE VACUUM BREAKER. An assembly containing an independently
operated spring loaded check valve and an independently operated spring loaded
air inlet valve located on the discharge side of the check valve. The assembly
includes tightly closing shutoff valves on each side of the valves and property
located test cocks for the testing of the check and air valve.
      (8)   REDUCED PRESSURE PRINCIPLE BACKFLOW PREVENTER. An assembly
consisting of two independently operating approved check valves with an
automatically operating differential relief valve located between the two check
valves, tightly closing shutoff valves on each side of the check valves plus
properly located test cocks for the testing of the check valves and the relief
valve.
      (9)   RESIDENTIAL DUAL CHECK. A device consisting of two spring loaded,
independently operating check valves. Generally employed immediately downstream
of the water meter to act as a fixture isolation device.
   BACKPRESSURE. A condition in which the customer’s system pressure is greater
than the water purveyor’s system pressure.
   BACK-SIPHONAGE. The flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or substances
into the distribution pipes of a potable water system from any source other
than the primary source caused by the sudden reduction of pressure or negative
pressure in the potable water system.
   COMMUNITY WATER SYSTEM. A public water system that serves at least 25
residents year round or that has 15 service connections serving year round
residents.
   CONTAINMENT (EXTERNAL PROTECTION). A method of backflow prevention which
requires a backflow preventer assembly be installed after the meter and prior
to any water service entrance.
   CONTAMINANT. A substance that will impair the quality of potable water to a
degree that it creates a serious health hazard to the public leading to
poisoning or the spread of disease.
   CROSS-CONNECTION. Any actual or potential, direct or indirect, connection
between the public water system and an unapproved water supply or other source
of contamination or pollution.
   CUSTOMER. A CUSTOMER is described as a billing unit or service connection to
which drinking water is delivered by a public water system. A CUSTOMER may also
be identified as an owner.
   DEGREE OF HAZARD. The potential risk to health and the potential adverse
effects upon the public water system based on the probability of backflow
occurring and the type or nature of the contaminant. A “health hazard” is any
condition, device or practice which creates or may create a danger to health
and well being of the water consumer. A “severe health hazard” is any health
hazard (contaminant) that could be expected to result in a significant
morbidity or death. A “non-health hazard” (pollutant) is any condition that
could degrade the quality or adversely affect the public water system.
   DEVICE. A single body backflow preventer with one or two check valves that
cannot be tested and does not have shutoff valves or test cocks.
   FIXTURE ISOLATION (INTERNAL ISOLATION). A method of backflow prevention
where a backflow preventer is located to control a cross-connection or
potential source of contamination at an in-plant piece of equipment or process
location other than at a water service entrance.
   OWNER. Any person who has legal title to, license to operate, or resides in
a property or facility which is supplied drinking water from a public water
system. May also be referred to as a customer.
   PERSON. Any individual, partnership, company, public or private corporation,
political subdivision, agency of the state, instrumentality of the United
States or any other legal entity.
   POLLUTANT. A foreign substance that, if permitted to enter the public water
system, will degrade potable water quality so as to constitute a moderate
hazard , or impair the usefulness of the water to a degree which does not
create an actual hazard to the public health, but which does adversely and
unreasonably affect (appearance or color, odor, taste and the like) the water
for domestic use.
   POTABLE WATER. Water that is safe for human consumption as described by the
State Bureau for Public Health.
   PUBLIC WATER SYSTEM. Includes the works, auxiliaries, for the collection,
treatment, storage and distribution of drinking water from the source of supply
to a customer’s premises. May also be known as a WATER PURVEYOR.
   WATER PURVEYOR. The Municipal Water Department, Water Board, Public Service
District or other administrative authority invested with the authority and
responsibility for a public water system.
   WATER SERVICE ENTRANCE. The point in the customer’s water system beyond the
sanitary control of the public water system (water purveyor), generally
considered to be the outlet end of the water meter and always before any
unprotected branch water line.
   WEST VIRGINIA BUREAU FOR PUBLIC HEALTH (WVBPH). The State of West Virginia
Bureau for Public Health.
(Ord. passed 10-28-2004)
§ 52.05 ADMINISTRATION.
   (A)   The water purveyor will establish, operate and promote a cross-
connection and backflow prevention control program, to include the keeping of
necessary records, which fulfills the requirements of the WVBPH cross-
connections and backflow prevention regulations.
   (B)   The owner shall allow his or her property to be inspected for possible
cross-connections and backflow conditions, and shall follow the provisions of
the water purveyor’s program and the WVBPH cross-connections and backflow
prevention regulations where a cross-connection is permitted.
   (C)   If the water purveyor requires that the public water system be
protected by containment, the owner shall be responsible for the installation
and maintenance of the required backflow preventer assembly(blies) and for
water quality beyond the outlet end of the containment assembly(blies) and
could utilize fixture isolation protection for that purpose. The owner may also
seek local public health officials or personnel from the water purveyor, or
their designated representatives, or certified/licensed private sector
personnel to assist him or her in the survey of their facility(ties) and to
assist him or her in the selection of proper containment assemblies and/or
fixture isolation devices, and the proper installation of these assemblies/
devices.
(Ord. passed 10-28-2004)
§ 52.06 REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Water purveyor.
      (1)   On new installations, the water purveyor will provide an on-site
evaluation and/or inspection of plans in order to determine the type of
backflow preventer assembly(blies), if any, that will be required based on
actual or potential cross-connections and the degree of health hazards.
      (2)   For   existing prior to the start of this program, the water
purveyor will perform evaluations and inspections of plans and/or premises for
actual and potential cross-connections and backflow conditions and inform the
owner by letter of any collective action deemed necessary, the method of
achieving the correction, and the time allowed for the correction to be made.
Ordinarily, 90 days will be allowed. However, this time period may be shortened
depending upon the degree of hazard involved and the history of the device(s)/
assembly(blies) already in place.
      (3)   The water purveyor will not allow any actual or potential cross-
connection to remain unless it is protected by an approved air gap or backflow
preventer assembly(blies) and which must be regularly tested or inspected to
insure satisfactory operation.
      (4)   The water purveyor shall inform the owner by letter of any failure
to comply prior to a re-inspection. The water purveyor will allow an additional
15 days for the correction(s). In the event the owner fails to comply with the
necessary correction(s) by the time of a second re-inspection, the water
purveyor will inform the owner by letter, that the water service to the owner’s
premises will be terminated within a period not to exceed five days. In the
event that the owner informs the water purveyor of extenuating circumstances as
to why the correction(s) has not been made, a time extension may be granted by
the water purveyor, but in no case will exceed an additional 30 days.
      (5)   If the water purveyor determines at anytime that a serious threat
to the public health exists, water service will be terminated immediately.
      (6)   The water purveyor will conduct initial and follow-up premises
inspections to determine the nature of existing or potential hazards. The main
focus will be on high hazard industries and commercial premises.
      (7)   The water purveyor must report any backflow incident(s) occurring
in the public water system as soon as possible but no later than 24 hours after
the incident to the WVBPH.
   (B)   Owner.
      (1)   The owner shall be responsible for the elimination or protection of
all actual or potential cross-connections and/or backflow conditions on his or
her premises.
      (2)   The owner, after having been informed by a letter from the water
purveyor, shall at his or her expense, install, maintain and test, or have
tested, any and all backflow preventer assemblies on his or her premises.
      (3)   The owner shall correct within 30 days any malfunction of an air
gap or backflow preventer assembly(blies) which is revealed by periodic
inspection or testing. This may also involve the removal and/or replacement of
the backflow preventer assembly(blies).
      (4)   The owner shall inform the water purveyor of any proposed or
modified cross-connections and also any existing cross-connections of which the
owner is aware, but have not been found by the water purveyor.
      (5)   The owner shall not install a by-pass around any backflow preventer
assembly unless there is a backflow prevention assembly of the same type on the
bypass. Owners who cannot shut down operation for testing of the assembly
(blies) must supply additional assemblies necessary to allow testing to take
place.
      (6)   The owner shall install only backflow preventer assemblies approved
by the water purveyor or the WVBPH.
      (7)   The owner shall install backflow preventer assemblies in a manner
approved by the water purveyor and general industry standards.
      (8)   Any owner having a private well or other auxiliary water source
must have the approval of the water purveyor and the WVBPH if the well or
source is cross-connected to the water purveyor’s system. Permission to cross-
connect may be denied. The owner may be required to install a backflow
preventer assembly at the service entrance if a private water source is
maintained, even if it is not cross-connected to the water purveyor’s system.
      (9)   In the event the owner installs plumbing to provide potable water
for domestic purposes which is on the water purveyor’s side of a backflow
preventer assembly, such plumbing must have its own backflow preventer assembly
installed.
      (10)   The owner shall be responsible for the payment of all fees for
service, permits, periodic assembly testing, retesting in the case that a
backflow preventer assembly fells to operate correctly, and followup re-
inspections for noncompliance with water purveyor or WVBPH requirements.
      (11)   The owner must maintain for a minimum of three years records of
installation and removal, all testing, repair and maintenance for all
assemblies/devices in the owner’s water distribution system(s).
      (12)   The owner will report any backflow incident(s) occurring in their
facility(ties)/building(s) as soon as possible but no later than 24 hours after
the incident to the water purveyor and to the WVBPH. Also, the owner must
maintain for a minimum of three years all records and reports of all backflow
incidents occurring in their facility(ties)/building(s). These records and
reports are to be made available to the water purveyor and/or WVBPH upon
request.
(Ord. passed 10-28-2004)
§ 52.07 DEGREE OF HAZARD.
   The water purveyor recognizes the threat to the public water system arising
from cross-connections and backflow conditions. All threats will be classified
by degree of hazard which will determine the requirements for the installation
of approved backflow preventer assemblies.
(Ord. passed 10-28-2004)
§ 52.08 EXISTING IN-USE BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICES.
   Any existing backflow preventer assembly shall be allowed by the water
purveyor to continue in service unless the degree of hazard is such as to
supersede the effectiveness of the present backflow preventer assembly, or
there is an unreasonable risk to the public health. Where the degree of hazard
has increased, as in the case of a residential installation converting to a
business establishment; any existing backflow preventer assemblies must be
upgraded to a reduced pressure principle assembly or a reduced pressure
principle assembly must be installed in the event that no backflow preventer
assembly is present.
(Ord. passed 10-28-2004)
§ 52.09 PERIODIC TESTING.
   (A)   Backflow preventer assemblies shall be tested and inspected at least
annually.
   (B)   Periodic testing shall be performed by a WVBPH certified tester. This
testing will be done at the owner’s expense.
   (C)   Any backflow preventer assembly which fails during a periodic test
will be repaired or replaced. When repairs are necessary, upon completion of
the repair, the assembly will be retested at the owner’s expense to ensure
correct operation. High hazard situations will not be allowed to continue
unprotected if the backflow preventer assembly fails the periodic test and
cannot be repaired immediately. In other situations, a compliance date of not
more than 30 days after the test date may be established. The owner is
responsible for the costs of all testing, repair service, replacement parts or
a replacement assembly. Parallel installation of two assemblies is an effective
means of the owner ensuring uninterrupted water service during testing or
repair of one of the assemblies and is strongly recommended when the owner
desires such continuity.
   (D)   Backflow preventer assemblies will be tested more frequently than
specified in division (A) of this section in cases where there is a history of
test failures and the water purveyor feels that due to the degree of hazard
involved, additional testing is warranted. Cost of the additional tests will be
borne by the owner.
(Ord. passed 10-28-2004)
§ 52.10 RECORDS.
   (A)   The water purveyor will initiate and maintain (update) the following:
      (1)   Master files on customer evaluations and/or inspections of cross-
connections and backflow conditions;
      (2)   Master files on all customer backflow preventer assemblies;
      (3)   Master files on customer backflow preventer tests, repairs and
replacements. Records for replaced backflow preventer shall be maintained for a
period of one year after date of removal from service;
      (4)   Records and reports of any backflow incident(s) occurring in the
public or consumer water systems shall be maintained for at least three years
after the date of the incident; and
      (5)   Copies of any of the above and other records and/or reports
supplied to the WVBPH. This material shall be maintained for at least three
years after submission.
   (B)   Upon request, the water purveyor will submit records of inspection and
noncompliance, surveys, tests results and/or corrective actions, and backflow
incident reports to the West Virginia Bureau for Public Health.
(Ord. passed 10-28-2004)
CHAPTER 53: WATER
Section
   
53.01   Kopperston Public Service District
   
53.02   Rates, charges and fees for water services
   
53.03   Private fire protection; rates, charges and fees for water services
§ 53.01 KOPPERSTON PUBLIC SERVICE DISTRICT.
   The acquisition of the Kopperston Public Service District water system by
the town, upon the Public Service Commission of West Virginia’s approval of
Kopperston Public Service District’s conveyance of the water system to the
town, and subject of bondholder approval, is approved.
(Ord. passed 9-19-1996; Ord. passed 10-20-2016; Ord. passed 4-25-2017; Ord.
passed 7-12-2018)
§ 53.02 RATES, CHARGES AND FEES FOR WATER SERVICES.
   The present rates and charges of the municipally operated water public
utility of the town charged for providing water services to its customers, be
and hereby are increased by providing for monthly rates and charges under the
following schedule of rates and charges for furnishing water services.
   (A)   Applicability. Applicable in entire territory served, including the
former customers of the Kopperston Public Service District.
   (B)   Availability. Available for general residential, commercial,
industrial and sale for resale water service.
   (C)   Rates (customers with metered water supply).
 
First 3,000 gallons used per month  $15.91 per 1,000 gallons
Next 3,000 gallons used per month   $13.70 per 1,000 gallons
Next 94,000 gallons used per month  $9.41 per 1,000 gallons
Over 100,000 gallons used per month $8.14 per 1,000 gallons
 
   (D)   Flat rate charge (customers with non-metered water supply). Equivalent
to 4,500 gallons of water usage, $68.27 per month.
   (E)   Minimum charges. The above schedule is subject to a monthly minimum
charge based on the size of the meter as follows:
5/8 x 3/4 inch meter, or smaller $47.73 per month
3/4 inch meter                   $71.59 per month
1 inch meter                     $119.32 per month
1-1/4 inch meter                 $174.22 per month
1-1/2 inch meter                 $238.64 per month
2 inch meter                     $381.83 per month
3 inch meter                     $715.93 per month
4 inch meter                     $1,193.22 per month
6 inch meter                     $2,386.44 per month
8 inch meter                     $3,818.31 per month
 
   (F)   Sales for resale service.
 
Kopperston Public Service District $5.91 per 1,000 gallons
 
   (G)   Returned check charge. A service charge equal to the actual bank fee
assessed to the town or a maximum of $30 will be imposed upon any customer
whose check for payment of charges is returned by the bank for any reason.
   (H)   Delayed payment penalty. The above schedule is net. On all accounts
not paid within 20 days of the date of the bill, 10% will be added to the
current net charge. This delayed payment penalty is not interest and is to be
collected only once for each bill where it is appropriate.
   (I)   Tap fee. The following charges are to be made whenever the utility
installs a new tap to serve an applicant.
      (1)   A tap fee of $100 will be charged to customers applying for service
before construction is bid in connection with a certificate proceeding before
the Public Service Commission. This pre- construction tap fee will be invalid
after the bidding of the construction project that is associated with the
certificate proceeding.
      (2)   A tap fee of $700 will be charged to all customers (three-fourths
inch or smaller) who apply for service outside of a certificate proceeding
before the Public Service Commission for each new tap to the system.
      (3)   All taps greater than three-fourths inch shall be charged the
greater of $700 or the actual cost of the connection, as determined by the
town.
   (J)   Leak adjustment. $2.26 per 1,000 gallons used when the bill reflects
unusual consumption which is attributable to eligible leakage on the customer’s
side of the meter. This rate shall be applied to all such unusual consumption
above the customer’s historical average usage.
   (K)   Debt service reserve recovery surcharge. A surcharge of $4 per
customer per month shall be imposed on all classes of service, with the
specific exception of sales for resale (Kopperston PSD) for recovery of debt
service deficiencies. This surcharge shall remain in effect until further
action of the town.
   (L)   Security deposit. A deposit of $50 or two-twelfths of the average
annual usage of the applicant’s specific customer class, whichever is greater.
This fee may be changed by applicable statutory provisions.
   (M)   Emergency customer convenience or seasonal turn on or off. There shall
be a $5 charge for each visit to the customer’s premises for such turn on or
off, except that if the service is both turned off and on within the same
eight-hour work day, only one $5 fee shall apply.
   (N)   Transfer of service. Transfer of service from one customer to another
will involve a $25 charge to the new customer for institution of account. Other
conditions will constitute a $5 charge.
   (O)   Reconnection charge. There shall be a $50 charge paid prior to
restoration of water service which had been disconnected for any reason. This
charge shall also apply as an administrative fee when bills are collected at
the customer’s residence or any place other than the billing office, or in the
event the bill is paid after disconnection has been commenced (utility workers
have traveled to the residence).
   (P)   Testing or replacement of meter at customer’s request. Upon request of
any customer of the system, the town will test or replace the customer’s water
meter as soon as is reasonably possible, and if the meter is found to be
defective, the customer’s account will be adjusted accordingly. If the meter is
found to be accurate within the prescribed guidelines of the Public Service
Commission of the state, then the customer’s account will receive no adjustment
and will be billed a charge of $25 for meter replacement.
   (Q)   Multiple occupancy. On apartment building or other multiple occupancy
buildings, each family or business unit shall be required to pay not less than
the minimum monthly charge herein for a five-eighths inch meter. Motels and
hotels shall pay according to the size of meter installed.
   (R)   Trailer courts.
      (1)   When house trailer courts are provided with a master meter, no bill
shall be rendered for less than $10.95, multiplied by the number of units
situated on the court site at the time the meter is read or the actual charge
for the size meter installed, whichever is greater. House trailer (as used
herein above) shall include both mobile and immobile units.
      (2)   House trailers either mobile or immobile, located on sites other
than a park or court, shall be billed in the same manner as any other family or
business unit.
   (S)   Payment collection fees. In the event that an employee of the town
collects a payment from the customer at the customer’s residence to avoid
termination of water service, the customer shall be charged a fee of $20, in
addition to the amount of any unpaid bill.
   (T)   Fee for installation of removed meter. If a water meter is removed to
prevent a customer from illegally obtaining water after the customer’s service
has been disconnected for nonpayment, the customer shall pay a minimum meter
re-installation fee of $125 plus additional charges to replace and or repair
damaged equipment belonging to the utility, before the meter is re-installed
and water service is reinstated. This fee is in addition to any re-connection
fees. If the customer’s service has been cut off by the request of a renter
vacating a rented dwelling, this charge will be made to the owner of the
building.
   (U)   EFT payments. A service charge will be imposed on EFT payments.
Payment shall consist of the actual charges from the financial institution for
processing payment.
   (V)   Bill reprint fee. A charge of $1 will be assessed to customers who do
not present the bar coded section of the bill provided by the utility with
payment.
(Ord. passed 8-5-2016; Ord. passed 10-9-2024)
§ 53.03 PRIVATE FIRE PROTECTION; RATES, CHARGES AND FEES FOR WATER SERVICES.
   (A)   Schedule II.
      (1)   Availability. The town’s water service under Schedule II shall be
available for private fire protection.
      (2)   Rate.
         (a)   Where connections, hydrants, sprinklers and the like on private
property are maintained by the consumer:
 
2 inch service line with hydrants, sprinklers and/or hose  $ 7.50 per month
connections
3 inch service line with hydrants, sprinklers and/or hose  $ 9 per month
connections
4 inch service line with hydrants, sprinklers and/or hose  $12 per month
connections
6 inch service line with hydrants, sprinklers and/or hose  $20 per month
connections
8 inch service line with hydrants, sprinklers and/or hose  $36 per month
connections
10 inch service line with hydrants, sprinklers and/or hose $60 per month
connections
12 inch service line with hydrants, sprinklers and/or hose $90 per month
connections
 
         (b)   Where connections and hydrants on private property are
maintained by the town:
 
Each fire hydrant $30 per month
 
   (B)   Step 2. (Effective upon substantial completion of the Phase 2 Project
or six months prior to the first Phase 2 Project DWTRF loan debt service
payment, whichever occurs earlier.)
      (1)   Applicability. Applicable in entire territory served, including the
former customers of Kopperston Public Service District.
      (2)   Availability. Available for general residential, commercial,
industrial and sale for resale water service.
      (3)   Rates. Customers with metered water supply:
 
First 3,000 gallons used per month  $16.91 per 1,000 gallons
Next 3,000 gallons used per month   $14.56 per 1,000 gallons
Next 94,000 gallons used per month  $10 per 1,000 gallons
Over 100,000 gallons used per month $8.65 per 1,000 gallons
 
      (4)   Flat rate charge. Customers with non-metered water supply:
 
Equivalent to 4,500 gallons of water usage $72.57 per month
 
      (5)   Minimum charges. The above schedule is subject to a monthly minimum
charge based on the size of the meter as follows:
5/8 x 3/4 inch meter, or smaller $50.73 per month
3/4    inch meter             $76.10 per month
1 inch meter                     $126.83 per month
1 1/4 inch meter                 $185.19 per month
1 1/2 inch meter                 $253.68 per month
2 inch meter                     $405.88 per month
3 inch meter                     $761.04 per month
4 inch meter                     $1,268.39 per month
6 inch meter                     $2,536.79 per month
8 inch meter                     $4,058.86 per month
 
      (6)   Sales for resale service. Sales for resale service shall be at a
rate of $6.29 per 1,000 gallons.
      (7)   Returned check charge. A service charge equal to the actual bank
fee assessed to the town or a maximum of $30 will be imposed upon any customer
whose check for payment of charges is returned by the bank for any reason.
      (8)   Delayed payment penalty. The above schedule is net. On all accounts
not paid within 20 days of the date of the bill, 10% will be added to the
current net charge. This delayed payment penalty is not interest and is to be
collected only once for each bill where it is appropriate.
      (9)   Tap fees. The following charges are to be made whenever the utility
installs a new tap to serve an applicant.
         (a)   A tap fee of $100 will be charged to customers applying for
service before construction is bid in connection with a certificate proceeding
before the Public Service Commission. This pre-construction tap fee will be
invalid after the bidding of the construction project that is associated with
the certificate proceeding.
         (b)   A tap fee of $700 will be charged to all customers (three-
fourths inch or smaller) who apply for service outside of a certificate
proceeding before the Public Service Commission for each new tap to the system.
         (c)   All taps greater than three-fourths inch shall be charged the
greater of $700 or the actual cost of the connection, as determined by the
town.
      (10)   Leak adjustment. A rate of $2.26 per 1,000 gallons used when the
bill reflects unusual consumption which is attributed to eligible leakage on
the customer’s side of the meter. This rate shall be applied to all such
unusual consumption above the customer’s historical average usage.
      (11)   Security deposits. A deposit of $50 or two-twelfths of the average
annual usage of the applicant’s specific customer class, whichever is greater.
This fee may be changed by applicable statutory provisions.
      (12)   Emergency customer convenience or seasonal turn on or off. There
shall be a $5 charge for each visit to the customer’s premises for such turn on
or off, except that if the service is both turned off and on within the same
eight-hour work day, only one $5 fee shall apply.
      (13)   Transfer of service. Transfer of service from one customer to
another will involve a $25 charge to the new customer for institution of
account. Other conditions will constitute a $5 charge.
      (14)   Reconnection charge. There shall be a $50 charge paid prior to
restoration of water service which had been disconnected for any reason. This
charge shall also apply as an administrative fee when bills are collected at
the customer’s residence or any place other than the billing office, or in the
event the bill is paid after disconnection has been commenced (utility workers
have traveled to the residence).
      (15)   Testing or replacement of meter at customer’s request. Upon
request of any customer of the system, the town will test or replace the
customer’s water meter as soon as is reasonably possible, and if the meter is
found to be defective, the customer’s account will be adjusted accordingly. If
the meter is found to be accurate within the prescribed guidelines of the State
Public Service Commission, then the customer’s account will receive no
adjustment and will be billed a charge of $25 for meter replacement.
      (16)   Multiple occupancy. On apartment building or other multiple
occupancy buildings, each family or business unit shall be required to pay not
less than the minimum monthly charge herein for a five-eighths inch meter.
Motels and hotels shall pay according to the size of meter installed.
      (17)   Trailer courts.
         (a)   When house trailer courts are provided with a master meter, no
bill shall be rendered for less than $10.95, multiplied by the number of units
situated on the court site at the time the meter is read or the actual charge
for the size meter installed, whichever is greater. House trailer (as used
herein above) shall include both mobile and immobile units.
         (b)   House trailers, either mobile or immobile, located on sites
other than a park or court shall be billed in the same manner as any other
family or business unit.
      (18)   Payment collection fees. In the event that an employee of the town
collects a payment from the customer at the customer’s residence to avoid
termination of water service, the customer shall be charged a fee of $20, in
addition to the amount of any unpaid bill.
      (19)   Fee for installation of removed meter. If a water meter is removed
to prevent a customer from illegally obtaining water after the customer’s
service has been disconnected for nonpayment, the customer shall pay a minimum
meter re-installation fee of $125 plus additional charges to replace and or
repair damaged equipment belonging to the utility, before the meter is re-
installed and water service is reinstated. This fee is in addition to any re-
connection fees. If the customer’s service has been cut off by the request of a
renter vacating a rented dwelling, this charge will be made to the owner of the
building.
      (20)   EFT payments. A service charge will be imposed on EFT payments.
Payment shall consist of the actual charges from the financial institution for
processing payment.
      (21)   Bill reprint fee. A charge of $1 will be assessed to customers who
do not present the bar coded section of the bill provided by the utility with
payment.
(Ord. passed 10-9-2024)
