§ 153.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   APARTMENT. A division in a house or building, consisting of one or more
rooms, which is designated for, intended for, or occupied by one or more
persons, for living purposes.
   AUTOMOBILE WRECKING. See JUNKYARD.
   BLOCKS. That property abutting on one side of a street and lying between the
two nearest intersecting or intercepting streets and railroad rights-of-way or
un-subdivided acreage.
   BUILDING ACCESSORY. A subordinate structure, use of which is incidental to
that of a main building.
   COUNCIL. The elective legislative body of the Town of Oceana.
   COURT AND AREA-WAYS. An open, unoccupied space, other than a yard, which is
bounded on two or more sides by a building or buildings, including the open
space in a house court or court apartment providing access to the units
thereof.
   FAMILY. One or more persons occupying a premises and living as a single,
non-profit housekeeping unit, as distinguished from a group occupying a hotel,
club, fraternity or sorority house. A FAMILY shall be deemed to include
necessary servants.
   GARAGE, PRIVATE. An accessory building for only the storage of self-
propelled vehicles.
   GARAGE, PUBLIC. Any premises, except those herein defined as a private or
storage garage, used for the storage of care of self-propelled vehicles or
where any such vehicles are equipped for operation or repair, or kept for hire
or sale.
   GARAGE, STORAGE. Any premises, except those herein defined as a private
garage, used exclusively for the storage of self-propelled vehicles.
   HEIGHT OF BUILDING. The vertical distance from the average level of the
highest and lowest point of the portion of the lot covered by the building to
the ceiling of the topmost story.
   HOME OCCUPATIONS. Any use customarily conducted entirely within a dwelling
and carried on by the inhabitants thereof, which is clearly incidental and
secondary to the use of the dwelling for dwelling purposes and does not change
the character thereof. Clinics, hospitals, barber shops, beauty shops and
animal hospitals shall not be deemed to be HOME OCCUPATIONS.
   HOTEL. Any building or portion thereof containing six or more guest rooms
used, designed or intended to be used, let or hired out to be occupied, or
which are occupied by six or more transient guests for compensation, whether
the compensation be paid directly or indirectly.
   JUNKYARD. The use of any land for the storage or keeping of junk, including
scrap metals, wood and other substances, or for the dismantling or wrecking of
automobiles, or other vehicles or machines.
   LOT. Land occupied or to be occupied by a building and its accessory
buildings, or by a dwelling group and its accessory buildings, together with
such open spaces as are required under the provisions of this chapter, having
not less than the minimum area required by this chapter for a building site in
the district in which such land is situated, and fronting on a street or alley.
   LOT, AREA OF. The total horizontal area included within lot lines, including
one-half of the width, but not to exceed ten feet, of any alley or portion
thereof, abutting any such lot line.
   LOT CORNER. A lot situated at the intersection of two or more streets, or
bounded on two or more adjacent sides by street lines.
   LOT, DEPTH OF. The average distance from the street line of the lot to its
rear line measured in the general direction of the side lines of the lot.
   LOT, INTERIOR. A lot other than a corner lot.
   LOT LINE, REAR. Ordinarily, that line of a lot which is generally opposite
the lot line along the frontage of said lot. In cases in which this definition
is not applicable the Planning and Zoning Commission shall designate the REAR
LOT LINE.
   MAYOR. The elected Mayor of the Town of Oceana or to his or her authorized
representative.
   MOBILE HOME. A structure designed or intended for human occupancy,
including, but not limited to, the following structures.
      (1)   FACTORY-BUILT HOME. Any dwelling commonly referred to as a mobile
home, house trailer, or recreational or camping or travel trailer.
      (2)   FOLD-DOWN CAMPING TRAILER. Any vehicle consisting of a portable
unit mounted on wheels and constructed with collapsible partial sidewalls which
fold for towing by another vehicle and unfold at the camp site to provide
temporary living quarters for recreational, camping, or travel use.
      (3)   HOUSE TRAILER. Any trailer designed or intended for human occupancy
and commonly referred to as a mobile home or house trailer, and including
recreational and camping and travel trailers when used on a non-recreational
basis.
      (4)   MOBILE HOME. Any transportable structure wholly or in substantial
part made in manufacturing facilities for installation or assembly on a
building site and designed for long-term residential use as a dwelling.
      (5)   RECREATIONAL VEHICLE. Any internally propelled vehicle mounted on
wheels and designed to provide temporary living quarters for recreational,
camping or travel use.
      (6)   TRAILER. Any vehicle mounted on wheels and designed to provide
temporary living quarters for recreational, camping or travel use.
      (7)   TRAVEL TRAILER. Any vehicle mounted on wheels and designed to
provide temporary living quarters for recreational, camping or travel use of
such size or weight as not to require special highway movement permits when
towed by a motor vehicle
   MOBILE HOME DISTRICT. One or more parcels of land under single or common
ownership upon which two or more mobile homes are located on a continual, non-
recreational basis together with any structure, equipment, road or facility
intended for use incidental to the occupancy of the mobile homes; provided,
that this definition excludes premises used solely for storage or display of
uninhabited mobile homes offered for sale on the open market.
   NONCONFORMING USE. A use that does not conform to the regulations for the
district in which it is situated.
   SIGN. Any thing, consisting of any material, conveying any information to
the public, including, but not limited to, placards, paintings and statuary,
whether indoors or outdoors.
   STORY. That portion of a building included between the surface of any floor
and the surface of the next floor above it or if there is no floor above it,
then the space between the floor and the ceiling next above it.
   STORY, HALF. A story with at least two opposite exterior sides meeting a
sloping roof not more than two feet above the floor of such story.
   STRUCTURE. Any thing constructed or erected, the use of which required
location on the ground or attachment to something having location on the
ground.
   STRUCTURAL ALTERATIONS. Any change in the supporting members of a building
such as bearing walls, columns, beams or girders.
   SUBDIVISION. A division of a lot, tract or parcel of land into two or more
lots, plots, sites or other divisions of land for any purpose, whether for
immediate or future use. This term includes re-subdivision.
   TOWN. The Town of Oceana, West Virginia.
   USE. The purpose for which land or premises or a building thereon is
designed, arranged or intended or for which it is or may be occupied or
maintained.
   USE, ACCESSORY. A use incidental and necessary to the principal use of a lot
or building located on the same lot.
   YARD. An open space other than a court on the same lot with a building,
which open space is unoccupied and unobstructed from the ground upward, except
as otherwise provided in §
153.09. In measuring a yard, as hereinafter provided, the line of a building
shall be deemed to mean a line parallel to the nearest lot line drawn through
the point of a building, or the point of a dwelling group, nearest to such lot
line, exclusive of the respective architectural features enumerated in §
153.09 as not to be considered in measuring yard dimensions or as being
permitted to extend into any front, side or rear yard, respectively; and the
measurement shall be taken from the line of the building to the nearest lot
line.
   YARD, FRONT. A yard extending across the front of the lot between the inner
side yard lines and lying between the front line of the lot and the nearest
line of the building.
   YARD, REAR. A yard extending across the full width of the lot and lying
between the rear line of the lot and the nearest line of the lot to the rear
line of the lot.
(Ord. passed 2-10-2000)
§ 153.02 ESTABLISHMENT OF DISTRICTS.
   (A)   For the purpose of this chapter the town is divided into the following
use districts: Residential; Mobile Home; and Commercial.
   (B)   Any land which may be added to the town in the future shall be placed
in the Residential District until special action of the Town Council as
hereinafter provided shall definitely assign such land to another use district.
   (C)   To more clearly set forth the boundaries of the original use districts
the same are hereby described as follows.
      (1)   Commercial. All property in the Town of Oceana abutting on West
Virginia Route 10 and extending back from the right-of-way of said Route 10 for
a distance of 100 feet. Property on West Virginia Routes 85 and 971, extending
back from the right-of-way of said West Virginia Routes 85 and 971 for a
distance of 100 feet may be designated as Commercial or Residential by the
property owner.
      (2)   Mobile home. All property bounded as described within Appendix A
“Mobile Home District Boundaries” attached hereto and incorporated herein.
      (3)   Residential. All other property not included in the Commercial
District and Mobile Home District as stated above shall be considered as
residential property.
(Ord. passed 2-10-2000; Ord. passed 6-14-2018)
§ 153.03 EFFECT OF ESTABLISHMENT OF DISTRICTS.
   Except as hereinafter otherwise provided:
   (A)   No building shall be erected and no existing building shall be moved,
altered, added to-or enlarged, nor shall any land, building or premises be
used, designed or intended to be used for any purpose or in any matter other
than as included above the uses hereinafter listed as permitted in the district
in which such building, land or premises is located;
   (B)   No building shall be erected, reconstructed or structurally altered to
exceed in height the limit hereinafter designated for the district in which
such building, land or premises is located;
   (C)   No building shall be erected, nor shall any existing building be
altered, enlarged or rebuilt, nor shall any open space surrounding any building
be encroached upon or reduced in any manner, except in conformity to the yard,
building site area and building location regulations hereinafter designated for
the district in which such building or open space is located; and
   (D)   (1)   Any yard or other open space provided by any building for the
purpose of complying with the provisions of this chapter shall be considered as
providing a yard or open space for any building and any yard or open space on
one lot shall be considered as providing a yard or open space for a building or
any other lot insofar and only insofar as that all of said lots provided the
yard or open space or any building or part of any building erected or placed
upon any said lot or any part of any building erected or placed upon any said
lot is owned by one and the same party to the effect that in compliance with
yard requirements a person may own two or more lots together and to place a
building across the dividing lines between said lots and in such cases of the
said two or more lots owned by one and the same party and individual lot if
more than one adjoining, adjacent and contiguous lots are owned by one and the
same party and used by said party for the purpose of one resident or one
business establishment.
      (2)   In any other event no yard or other open space provided by any
building for the purpose of complying with the provisions of this chapter shall
be considered if providing a yard or open space for any other building and no
yard or other open space on one lot shall be considered as providing a yard or
open space providing a building or any other lot.
(Ord. passed 2-10-2000)
§ 153.04 REGULATIONS FOR RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS.
   (A)   Use regulations. In the Residential District, unless otherwise
provided in this chapter, no building or land shall be used and no building
shall hereinafter be erected or structurally altered except for one or more of
the following cases:
      (1)   One- or two-family dwellings and their accessory buildings,
apartments;
      (2)   Farming or truck gardening; plant nurseries or greenhouses;
      (3)   Parks and playgrounds; golf courses or golf clubs;
      (4)   Churches, libraries, museums, schools, memorial buildings,
including name plates and bulletin boards placed in back of the prescribed set
back lines;
      (5)   Boarding and lodging houses;
      (6)   Home occupations;
      (7)   The following uses, but only upon securing a special use permit as
provided in §
153.12:
         (a)   Hospitals, clinics and other buildings used for the treatment of
human ailment;
         (b)   Philanthropic and charitable institutions;
         (c)   Radio or television broadcasting stations; and
         (d)   Clubs, lodges, fraternities and sorority houses.
      (8)   Any other use requires approval by a majority vote of the Town
Council upon application for a special use permit; and
      (9)   Any previously established business that exists in an area which is
zoned residential can stay located in that area which is zoned residential;
however, no new business can exist from this day forward in an area which zoned
is residential.
   (B)   Mobile homes. Nothing defined herein as a mobile home shall be
permitted in the Residential District, except as a nonconforming use pursuant
to §
153.09 and except under a special use permit pursuant to §
153.12. Notwithstanding any provision of this chapter, no mobile home shall be
used for residential purposes in the Commercial District.
   (C)   Height regulations. In the Residential District no building shall
hereafter be erected or structurally altered to exceed 40 feet or three stories
in height.
   (D)   Area regulations.
      (1)   Building site regulations. In the Residential District every
building designed for the housing of one or two families together with its
accessory buildings, shall be located on a building site in one ownership
having an area of at least 3,000 square feet. Every building designed for more
than two families shall be located on a building site in one ownership having
not less than 1,800 square feet per family.
      (2)   Front yard requirements. No portion of a house shall be built
closer than 20 feet to the front line on the lot, exclusive of porches, eaves
and the like.
      (3)   Side yard requirements.
         (a)   Each lot in a Residential District shall have its side yards one
on each side of the building. For every dwelling hereinafter erected or
structurally altered which does not exceed two stories, each side yard shall
have a width of not less than five feet; and in the event that one person shall
own two or more lots adjacent and adjoining to each other and shall use both
lots for a single dwelling then the side yard requirements herein imposed shall
apply as to the exterior boundary line of said adjacent and adjoined
combination of lots and shall not apply to each lot individually.
         (b)   On corner lots which abut on two or more streets the side yard
on the street side of such corner lots and which side also abuts on said side
street, shall have a width of 20 feet.
         (c)   In case a dwelling is so located on a lot that the front or rear
thereof faces any side lot line, such dwelling shall not be less than 20 feet
from said line.
      (4)   Rear yard requirements. No portion of any house shall be built
closer than ten feet to the back line of the lot with the exception of porches,
eaves and the like.
(Ord. passed 2-10-2000; Ord. passed 2-8-2007)
§ 153.05 REGULATIONS FOR MOBILE HOME DISTRICTS.
   (A)   Generally. All regulations set forth in §
153.04 are incorporated herein and apply to all Mobile Home Districts.
   (B)   Placement regulations.
      (1)   Indemnity bond.
         (a)   Ten days before moving any mobile home within the town for the
purpose of placement within the town, the owner of the mobile home shall post
an indemnity bond in the amount of $2,000 with the Town Recorder for the
purpose of indemnifying the town against damage to public property resulting
from movement of the mobile home.
         (b)   The indemnity bond shall be released by the Town Recorder within
30 days after movement of the mobile home is completed.
         (c)   If the town claims damage against the indemnity bond, any money
obtained from the bond shall be applied against repair of the property damage.
         (d)   If the amount of the bond is less than the cost of repairing any
damage to public property resulting from movement of the mobile home, the town
is not thereby precluded from instituting legal action for damages.
      (2)   Permit for placement.
         (a)   Thirty days before placement of any mobile home, the owner of
the mobile home shall submit to the Town Recorder an application for a
placement permit, which application shall provide the following information:
            1.   Metes and bounds description, street address or other
description of the property upon which the mobile home is to be placed;
            2.   Name, address and telephone number of the owner of the mobile
home;
            3.   Name, address and telephone number of the owner of the
property upon which the mobile home is to be placed;
            4.   Dimensions, model number, style or other description of the
mobile home, which shall include a photograph;
            5.   Name, address and telephone number of the person or entity
moving the mobile home;
            6.   Name, address and telephone number of the person or entity
underwriting the bond for movement of the mobile home; and
            7.   Other information required by the Town Council.
         (b)   The application for placement shall include a non-refundable
placement fee of $50 paid by the owner of the mobile home;
         (c)   The Town Council shall require as prerequisite to the approval
of an application for placement permit an on-site inspection of the mobile home
or of the property upon which the mobile home is to be placed or both;
         (d)   The Building Commissioner shall within ten days of application
approve or reject the application for placement of mobile home, giving written
reasons for rejection and providing procedure for appeal, or directing the Town
Recorder to issue a permit;
         (e)   Appeal to Town Council shall be heard at the next regularly
scheduled meeting of Town Council or may at the discretion of the Mayor be
heard at a special meeting prior to the next regularly scheduled meeting. Upon
appeal, the Town Council may override the decision of the Building Commissioner
by a majority vote;
         (f)   The permit shall be at least eight and one-half by11 inches in
size and shall set forth the information required in the application, and may
consist of the application marked “Permit Approved”;
         (g)   Fifteen days before placement of any mobile home, the permit
shall be posted upon the property upon which the mobile home is to be placed;
         (h)   Through the fifth business day before the day of placement of
the mobile home, and not including the day of placement, any citizen of the
town may submit a written protest and request for public hearing;
         (i)   Upon written request for public hearing, the Town Council shall
convene for the purpose of conducting the public hearing at the next regularly
scheduled meeting of Town Council, or may at the discretion of the Mayor
convene for a special meeting prior to the next regularly scheduled meeting;
both proponents and opponents of the placement of the mobile home shall be
afforded equal opportunity to be heard; the Town Council shall vote upon and
shall issue its ruling by majority vote immediately upon completion of the
public hearing.
      (3)   Structural requirements. Any mobile home hereafter placed within
the town shall have the following structural elements:
         (a)   Masonry foundation;
         (b)   Steps to each entryway; and
         (c)   Underpinning or skirting of wood, plywood, masonite, fiberboard,
wood or polyvinyl chloride latticework, or other material specifically approved
by Town Council, excluding corrugated plastic, cloth, sheet vinyl or paper,
which shall enclose the entire perimeter of the mobile home.
      (4)   Specifications.
         (a)   The minimum size of an individual mobile home site or lot within
a Mobile Home District created after the enactment of this chapter shall be
3,000 square feet;
         (b)   The minimum site for a Mobile Home District created after the
enactment of this chapter shall be two acres;
         (c)   The setbacks and lot or site placement for mobile homes shall be
the same as for residential homes, but front and side yard requirements shall
be applied in the aggregate for the entire Mobile Home District and not for
each individual mobile home therein; and
         (d)   In addition to signs permitted for the Residential District,
each Mobile Home District shall be permitted one sign not to exceed eight
square feet identifying the Mobile Home District and otherwise complying with
regulations for signs within this chapter.
      (5)   Permit for Mobile Home District. The creation of any Mobile Home
District not existing at the time of adoption of this section requires
application and creation by new ordinance. The application must include a
development plan including, but not limited to, the following information:
         (a)   A map showing to scale the precise location of the proposed
Mobile Home District within the town;
         (b)   A metes and bounds description of the property;
         (c)   A construction time schedule;
         (d)   Existing and proposed contours, paving, roadways, walkways,
parking, open spaces, common areas, fences, plantings, lighting and signs;
         (e)   Proposed site location of individual mobile homes; and
         (f)   Provision of essential services including, but not limited to,
sewer, water, gas, electricity, telephone, and television cable conduits and
meters.
(Ord. passed 2-10-2000)
§ 153.06 REGULATIONS FOR COMMERCIAL DISTRICTS.
   (A)   Use regulations. In the Commercial District, unless otherwise provided
in this chapter, no building or land shall be used, and no building shall
hereinafter be erected or structurally altered except for one or more of the
following uses:
      (1)   All uses permitted in the Residential Districts;
      (2)   Retail stores and shops;
      (3)   Automobile stations for the sale of gasoline, oil and accessories,
public garages;
      (4)   Theaters, financial institutions, telephones and telegraph offices,
messenger offices, professional offices;
      (5)   Carpentry, furniture repairing or upholstering shops, book binding
shops, dress making shops, shoe repairing and dyeing shops, newspaper or job
printing establishment, electrical, metal working, tinsmithing, plumbing,
water, gas or steam fitting shops, paint or paper-hanging shops;
      (6)   Undertaking establishments, but only upon securing of special use
permit as provided in §
153.12;
      (7)   Other business uses which in the opinion of the Planning and Zoning
Commission or the Town Council, are of the same general character as the uses
enumerated in this division (A) and will not be obnoxious or detrimental to the
district in which located; and
      (8)   All industrial uses which, in the opinion of the Planning and
Zoning Commission or the Town Council will not be obnoxious or detrimental to
the district in which located, and then only upon the securing of a special use
permit as provided in §
153.12.
   (B)   Mobile home regulations.
      (1)   A structure defined as a mobile home may be used for commercial
purposes within the Commercial District if all regulations set forth within
this section are met.
      (2)   Notwithstanding division (A)(1) of this section, which provides for
residential uses in the Commercial District, and notwithstanding any other
provision of this chapter, no mobile home shall be used for residential
purposes in the Commercial District.
   (C)   Building and material regulations.
      (1)   Floor levels. The ground floor level of any business building or
other business structures shall be in conformity with the present sidewalk
levels and elevations in said town, or as hereinafter established and in
conformity with the establishment grade of all streets not having sidewalks and
said floor level shall not extend above said sidewalk level or road grade level
more than eight inches nor shall said floor level be below said sidewalk or
road grade level more than six inches.
      (2)   Walls parallel to street line. The wall of any business building or
structure on the street side thereof shall be parallel to the sidewalk in front
of said lot or parallel to the right of any line of any street in front
thereof, if said street has no sidewalk.
      (3)   Walls. The thickness of masonry bearing walls shall not be less
than eight inches for the first story in height; provided, that they do not
exceed two stories in height.
         (a)   Should they exceed two stories in height, they shall be
increased four inches for each successive two stories. Non-bearing walls may be
eight inches thick for the first 50 feet.
         (b)   Hollow walls of brick or walls of hollow burned clay, tile or
concrete blocks or cinder blocks shall not be used as bearing walls for
structures exceeding three stories in height.
         (c)   The thickness of walls of reinforced concrete bearing walls
shall not be less than three fourths of the thickness required for masonry
bearing walls.
         (d)   Walls of business buildings and storage buildings other than
fire walls or party walls, not more than one story in height, must be eight
inches thick.
         (e)   The above thickness of walls may be ordered increased if in the
opinion of the Planning and Zoning Commission or the Town Council, based upon
proposed use of the building or upon the terrain factor, additional thickness
is deemed necessary for the safety of lives and property.
      (4)   Fireproof construction. All public garages, public theaters, hotels
and all other buildings constructed or erected and to be used as a meeting
place for public assembly shall be of fireproof construction.
      (5)   Protection of ends of wooden beams.
         (a)   Wooden beams, joints or girders resting on opposite sides of a
masonry wall, shall be separated from one another by at least six inches of
solid masonry.
         (b)   Joists shall be cut in such manner that should they burn to the
center, the ends will drop free of the walls unless said joists shall be
supported by steel wall hangers.
      (6)   Quality of materials. All building materials shall be of good
quality and shall conform to specifications which the building officials
prescribe; more generally accepted standard specification for qualities of
materials are those of the American Society for Testing Materials.
      (7)   Electrical installation. All electrical living apparatus or
appliances, for furnishing light, heat or power, shall be in strict conformity
with the statutes of the state and the rules and regulations issued by the
Underwriters Laboratory, and in conformity with approved methods of
construction for safety to life and property.
      (8)   Code standards. Rules, regulations and recommendations as contained
in the National Building Code as recommended by the National Board of Fire
Underwriters shall be deemed prima facie evidence of the approved manner for
the construction and erection of all buildings in this use district.
(Ord. passed 2-10-2000; Ord. passed 6-14-2018)
§ 153.07 REGULATIONS FOR PROPERTY MAINTENANCE.
   (A)   Applicability.
      (1)   This section applies to all property within the town regardless of
its classification for use or taxation.
      (2)   No object, material or substance required to be screened or abated
pursuant to this section is exempt from the application and enforcement of this
section by virtue of §
153.09, nor shall any such object, material or substance be deemed to be
“grandfathered” or permitted to continue for any reason after the adoption and
implementation of this section.
   (B)   Screening.
      (1)   The following items within the town shall be completely screened
from view from any perspective:
         (a)   Any receptacle used for the disposal, storage or hauling of
trash; provided, that receptacles may be exposed to view within the 24 hours
encompassing the time of regularly scheduled trash pick-up;
         (b)   Any vehicle incapable of movement under its own power, except in
an emergency of less than 24 hours’ duration;
         (c)   Any vehicle under repair, whether mechanical, auto body or
interior repair, or in a state of being incomplete as to parts or surface
finish; and
         (d)   Any vehicle not having valid title and registration pursuant to
state law.
      (2)   Screening shall be as follows:
         (a)   Six inches in height higher than the top plane of the item to be
screened, as measured from the earth or pavement to the top edge of the screen
unit;
         (b)   Enclosing the entire perimeter of the storage area containing
the item to be screened;
         (c)   Constructed of substantial opaque rigid material including, but
not limited to, masonry, wood, masonite, fiberboard, rigid polyvinyl chloride
or other material specifically approved by Town Council, excluding corrugated
plastic, cloth, sheet vinyl or paper;
         (d)   Maintained as to surface and condition by painting, cleaning and
repair; and
         (e)   Placed upon a foundation or otherwise anchored to the earth or
pavement.
      (3)   Screening modification.
         (a)   Screening of dumpsters may be modified to accommodate the
dumpster pick-up mechanism.
         (b)   Dumpster screening may be subject to variance requirements at
the discretion of Town Council.
   (C)   Unlicensed vehicles prohibited. No vehicle requiring a state license
and bearing no such applicable license shall be parked or stored on any street
within the town limits except in an emergency of less than 24 hours’ duration.
   (D)   Materials subject to abatement. The growth, storage or accumulation of
materials including, but not limited to, plant growth or organic material,
trash, building or manufacturing materials or by-products, furniture,
appliances, tools, equipment, vehicles, toys, decorations or any other object
or substance not a building or appurtenance thereto, situated upon any property
within the town, may be deemed a public nuisance or may be deemed detrimental
to the health, safety or welfare of the residents of the town by majority vote
of the Town Council.
   (E)   Jurisdiction.
      (1)   Any property within the town is subject to the jurisdiction of the
Town Council with respect to property maintenance.
      (2)   The Town Council is empowered to enter upon any land within the
town for purposes of inspection and maintenance in compliance with procedure
set forth herein.
   (F)   Procedure.
      (1)   Any resident or official of the town may file a complaint alleging
violation of this section, which complaint shall be evidenced by completion of
a written complaint form provided by the Town Recorder, which form shall
include at least the name and address of the person filing the complaint and a
short and plain statement of the nature of the violation.
      (2)   The complaint form attached hereto as Appendix B may be revised by
majority vote of the Town Council as a technical revision, notwithstanding any
procedural requirements for the ordinance revision.
      (3)   Within ten days of the filing of a complaint, Town Council shall
refer any potential violation of this section to the Street Commissioner for
inspection.
      (4)   Upon referral of the complaint, the Street Commissioner shall
submit a report to the Town Council, and Town Council shall convene to receive
the report, at its next regularly scheduled meeting, or sooner as directed by
Town Council, and no more than 30 days after referral.
      (5)   Upon receipt of the report of the Street Commissioner, the Town
Council may by majority vote issue to the property owner a cease and desist
order and notice of hearing no more than ten days after receipt of the Street
Commissioner’s report and at least ten days before the hearing date.
      (6)   The cease and desist order shall state with specificity:
         (a)   Location of property;
         (b)   Name of property owner;
         (c)   Nature of alleged violation;
         (d)   Specific abatement, corrective maintenance or other action
required;
         (e)   Procedure for response and opportunity to be heard at least ten
days after service;
         (f)   Consequences of failure to respond or appear, including, but not
limited to, waiver of right, entry upon land, abatement at property owner’s
expense, potential lien against the property or money judgment for costs;
         (g)   Date on which Town Council will conduct a hearing, at least ten
days after service of the cease and desist order;
         (h)   Statement that the cease and desist order serves as notice of
hearing; and
         (i)   Statement advising property owner of right to legal
representation.
      (7)   On the date set forth within the cease and desist order, a hearing
shall be conducted by a quorum of the Town Council, which shall issue its
ruling in the form of an order within ten days of the hearing.
      (8)   The ruling order shall include one or more findings of fact and
conclusions of law with respect to the condition of the property and its status
as a public nuisance or as detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of the
residents of the town, and with respect to the abatement or maintenance
required, and shall state with specificity any remedy imposed, including, but
not limited to, requiring the property owner to abate the nuisance or implement
such maintenance as specified in the order, and requiring Town Council to
undertake the required abatement or property maintenance at the expense of the
property owner if the property owner fails to complete such maintenance within
a stated reasonable time frame of at least 30 days in the case of any nuisance
or detriment not constituting an emergency condition; provided, that failure of
the property owner to appear or respond at the hearing constitutes waiver and
enables the Town Council to undertake abatement or maintenance at the property
owner’s expense immediately.
      (9)   If the Town Council finds the property’s condition to be a nuisance
or detriment constituting an emergency condition, which emergency condition
must be supported by findings of fact set forth within the ruling order, the
property owner may be required to undertake abatement or maintenance
immediately, and, if the property owner fails to do so, Town Council may
undertake maintenance or abatement within five days.
      (10)   The cease and desist order and the ruling order shall be served
upon the property owner pursuant to the West Virginia Rules of Civil Procedure,
Rule 4, and any applicable section of state law.
      (11)   Upon issuance of its order, the Town Council may proceed to
effectuate the remedy stated therein pursuant to its terms.
      (12)   Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit or interfere
with the police power of the town or to prevent the town from taking
appropriate measures to abate emergency conditions requiring immediate action
on any land within the town.
(Ord. passed 2-10-2000)
Cross-reference:
   Property Maintenance Complaint For, see
Ch. 153, App. B
§ 153.08 GENERAL PROVISIONS AND EXCEPTIONS.
   The regulations specified in this chapter shall be subject to the following
interpretation and exceptions.
   (A)   Uses.
      (1)   The following accessory uses, in addition to those hereinbefore
specified shall be permitted in any Residential District; provided, that such
accessory uses do not alter the character of the premises in respect to their
use for the purpose permitted in such respective districts:
         (a)   The renting of rooms and/or the providing of table board in a
dwelling as an incidental use to that of its occupancy as a dwelling of the
character permitted in the respective district, but not to the extent of
constituting a hotel as defined in this chapter, unless permitted in the
district; and
         (b)   The operation of necessary facilities and equipment in
connection with schools, colleges, universities, hospitals and other
institutions permitted in the respective district.
      (2)   Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, no livestock
is permitted on any lot in any Residential or Mobile Home District.
      (3)   Signs are permitted within the boundaries of the town under the
following conditions.
         (a)   The area of signs permitted within this chapter shall be
measured as follows:
            1.   Area includes the entire area enclosing the extreme limits of
any representational image, including any frame, color or background
distinguishing it from the surface upon which it is placed;
            2.   Area is calculated by multiplying the longest vertical length
by the longest horizontal length of the entire image including its background;
            3.   Supports upon which a sign is displayed are not included in
the measurement of its area; and
            4.   Height is measured from the surface of the earth or pavement
underlying the sign to the top edge of the thing to be measured.
         (b)   Signs upon residential property shall not exceed one square foot
in area; provided, that a sign displayed upon residential property advertising
for sale the property upon which it is displayed, or a political sign displayed
within six months prior to a local, state or national election, shall not
exceed four square feet in area, and its uprights shall not exceed four feet in
height.
         (c)   Signs upon commercial property shall not exceed eight square
feet in area.
         (d)   No sign may extend into the vertical plane occupied by any paved
sidewalk or street.
         (e)   A sign advertising for sale of the property upon which it is
displayed, or a political sign displayed within six months prior or a local,
state or national election, may be affixed to a pole or upright structure not
exceeding four feet in height.
         (f)   Any commercial sign not flush against the surface of a building,
or otherwise projecting into unoccupied air space, must provide a clearance of
eight feet between the earth or pavement over which it is placed and the bottom
edge or surface of the sign.
         (g)   A sign placed upon Residential, Commercial, Mobile Home District
or public property may provide direction and location information, including,
but not limited to, directions to properties not situated adjacent to the
street upon which such sign is located, and such directional sign requires
application in advance for a permit subject to the majority approval of the
Town Council.
         (h)   A sign permit shall be obtained for the erection of any
commercial sign.
         (i)   Any sign in variance from the restrictions set forth herein
requires application in advance for a permit subject to the majority approval
of the Town Council.
      (4)   Building permits.
         (a)   Prior to site preparation or excavation, a building permit shall
be issued by the building inspector or other designated agent of Town Council
for any construction, alteration, wrecking or moving of any building structure
or appurtenance, within any Commercial, Residential or Mobile Home District.
         (b)   No building permit is necessary for ordinary cultivation or
landscaping.
         (c)   Within a Residential or Mobile Home District, no building permit
is necessary for construction, alteration, wrecking or moving of any building,
structure or appurtenance having construction value of less than $500.
         (d)   All cultivation, landscaping, excavation or construction of any
kind performed without a permit shall, nevertheless, comply with all applicable
construction requirements set forth in this chapter.
         (e)   The fee for a building permit, payable upon application, is $4
for the first $1,000 of construction value and $2 for each additional $1,000 of
construction value or portion thereof.
         (f)   Application for a building permit shall be submitted to the
building inspector or other designated agent of Town Council, on blank forms
furnished by the town.
         (g)   Each application for a building permit shall be accompanied by a
plan drawn to scale showing the dimensions of the subject building, structure
and appurtenance, including any applicable plot plan, also to scale. Each
application shall contain such other information Town Council deems necessary
for proper enforcement of the chapter.
         (h)   The building inspector or other designated agent of Town Council
shall determine whether the construction application and plane comply with the
ordinance and shall issue or reject the permit application accordingly.
      (5)   Nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to prohibit the
construction or maintenance of any stand or shelter for the sale of
agricultural products raised on the premises.
      (6)   No filling station, public garage or gasoline distributing station
shall be located within 300 feet of a school, church, hospital or other public
meeting place having a seating capacity of more than 50 persons.
   (B)   Yards.
      (1)   Generally. For the purpose of computing front yard dimensions
measurements shall be taken from the nearest point of the front wall of the
building to the street line, except that the certain architectural features
hereinafter enumerated shall not be considered in making such measurements:
         (a)   Cornices, canopies, eaves or any other architectural features
may extend beyond said front wall of distance not exceeding two feet, six
inches;
         (b)   Fire escapes may extend beyond said front wall a distance not
exceeding four feet, six inches;
         (c)   A landing place or uncovered porch may extend beyond said front
wall to a distance not exceeding six feet; provided, that such landing place or
porch shall have its floor no higher than the entrance floor of the building. A
railing no higher than three feet may be placed around such place; and
         (d)   The above enumerated architectural features may also extend into
any side or rear yard the same distance that they are permitted to extend
beyond any front wall, except that no porch, terrace, or outside stairway shall
project more than three feet into any side yard and then, in the case of an
outside stairway, only if the same is unroofed and unenclosed above and below
the steps thereof.
      (2)   Accessory buildings. In case an accessory building is attached to
the main building, it shall be made structurally a part thereof and shall
comply in all respects with the requirements of this chapter applicable to the
main building. An accessory building, unless attached to and made a part of the
main building as provided above for, shall not be closer than five feet to the
main building, except as otherwise provided in this section.
      (3)   Side yard requirements. In the Commercial District, no side yard
shall be required except as follows.
         (a)   Buildings erected or used for dwelling purposes exclusively
shall comply with the side yard regulations of the Residential District.
         (b)   Buildings erected or used for both dwelling and business
purposes shall have two side yards not less than five feet wide, one on each
side of the building, if any story of the building used in any part for
dwelling purposes is more than two rooms in depth; provided, that no such side
yard shall be necessary on the street side of a corner lot.
(Ord. passed 2-10-2000; Ord. passed 6-14-2018)
§ 153.09 NONCONFORMING USES.
   (A)   Except as otherwise provided in this section, the lawful use of any
land or building existing at the time of the adoption of this chapter may be
continued although such use does not conform to the regulations specified by
this chapter for the district in which such land or building is located;
provided, that no such nonconforming use of land shall be enlarged or increased
nor shall any such nonconforming use be extended to occupy a greater area of
land than that occupied by such use at the time of the adoption of this
chapter; nor shall any such nonconforming use be moved to any other part of the
parcel of land upon which the same was conducted at the time of the adoption of
this chapter. A nonconforming use of a building existing at the time of the
adoption of this chapter may be extended throughout the building; provided,
that no structural alterations except those required by ordinance or law are
made therein. If such nonconforming use consists of a substantial building and
ceases for a continuous period of two years, any subsequent use of said
building shall be in conformity to the regulations specified by this chapter
for the district in which the building is located; however, if any
nonconforming use of lands on which there are no substantial buildings ceases
for any length of time, any subsequent use of such land shall be in conformity
to regulations specified by this chapter for the district in which such land is
located. A mobile home is not a substantial building for purposes of this
section. Non-use of a nonconforming mobile home for a period of one year shall
terminate its status as a grandfathered nonconforming use and shall trigger a
requirement for conformity to this chapter.
   (B)   (1)   If at any time any building in existence or maintained at the
time of the adoption of this chapter which does not conform to the regulations
of the district in which it is located shall be destroyed by fire, earthquake,
wind, water or explosion, or any other cause, to the extent of more than 50% of
its value, then without further action by the Town Council the said building
and the land on which such building was located or maintained shall from the
date of said destruction be subject to the regulations specified by this
chapter for the district in which such land and building are located.
      (2)   Any building which is damaged to an extent of less than 50% of its
value may be restored to its former extent. Estimate of the extent of damage or
destruction shall be made by the Town Council or its appointed agents.
   (C)   Any use for which a use permit is required or for which a use permit
may be granted under the terms of this chapter, which use is existing at the
time of the adoption of this chapter, in any district in which such use is
specifically permitted subject to the security of a use permit, shall without
further action be deemed to be a conforming use in such district.
   (D)   Regardless of any other provisions of this chapter, no junkyard
existing as a nonconforming use in a Residential District at the time of the
adoption of this chapter shall continue as herein provided for nonconforming
use for more than one year from the adoption of this chapter. No junkyard which
after the adoption of this chapter exists as a nonconforming use in any
Commercial or Industrial District shall continue as herein provided for
nonconforming uses unless such junkyard shall within one year after it has
become a nonconforming use be completely enclosed within a building or within a
continuous solid fence not less than eight feet in height and in case of such
height as to screen completely all the operations of such junkyard. The plans
of such building or fence shall first have been approved by the Planning and
Zoning Commission. All other provisions of this section shall apply to any
nonconforming junkyard.
   (E)   Regardless of any other provisions of this chapter no outdoor
advertising structure existing as a nonconforming use at the time of the
adoption of this chapter shall continue as herein provided for nonconforming
uses for more than six months after the adoption of this chapter.
   (F)   Any mobile home existing within the town at the time of adoption of
this chapter, regardless of whether it is situated within a designated Mobile
Home District, shall, for a period of six months following adoption of this
chapter, be deemed a conforming use, and thereafter shall have installed
underpinning or skirting of wood, plywood, masonite, fiberboard, wood or
polyvinyl chloride latticework, or other material specifically approved by Town
Council, excluding corrugated plastic, cloth, sheet vinyl or paper, which shall
enclose the entire perimeter of the mobile home.
(Ord. passed 2-10-2000)
§ 153.10 PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION.
   (A)   Creation and membership.
      (1)   The powers exercised by the town under this chapter are granted by
W. Va. Code §§ 8-5-1 et seq. The municipal Planning and Zoning Commission
herein created is also vested in the powers of zoning herein expressly granted
to said Commission by virtue of the cited sections of the West Virginia Code.
      (2)   The Commission shall consist of not less than five members all of
whom shall be taxpayers and residents of the said town who shall be nominated
by the Mayor and confirmed by the legislative body of said town.
         (a)   Members of the Commission first appointed hereunder shall be
appointed to serve respectively for terms of one year, two years and three
years, divided equally or as nearly equal as possible between these terms;
thereafter members shall be appointed for terms of three years each and
vacancies shall be filled by appointment for the un-expired term only.
         (b)   Members of the Commission shall serve without compensation and
shall hold no other town office.
      (3)   In addition to the not less than five appointed members there shall
also be two ex officio members, who shall be the Mayor and one member of the
Town Council to be selected by its own members. The terms of the ex officio
members shall correspond to their official tenures.
      (4)   (a)   Members other than the members selected by the Town Council
may be removed from office by the Mayor, for inefficiency, neglect of duty or
malfeasance in office. Removal shall be made only after a public hearing for
charges against the members.
         (b)   The Town Council may for like cause the in like manner remove
the member appointed by it. The Mayor or Town Council, as the case may be,
shall file a written statement of reasons for such removal with the Commission
and with the Recorder of said town prior to the date set for the public hearing
on the charges.
      (5)   Vacancies occurring otherwise than through the expiration of term
shall be filled for the un-expired term in the same manner as in the case of
the original appointment.
   (B)   Organization and rules.
      (1)   (a)   The Commission shall elect its Chairperson from amongst the
appointed members and fill such other of its offices as it may determine.
         (b)   The term of the Chairperson shall be for one year with
eligibility for re-election.
      (2)   The Commission shall adopt rules for transaction of business and
shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and
determinations, which record shall be a public record.
   (C)   Staff and finances.
      (1)   Subject to the provisions and limitations set forth herein the
Commission may appoint such employees as it may deem necessary for its work,
whose appointment, promotion, demotion or removal shall be subject to the same
provisions of law as govern corresponding civil members of the town; and may
also contract with town planners, engineers, architects and other consultants
for such service as it may require.
      (2)   The Commission may receive gifts of money for the purposes of this
chapter which moneys shall be paid into the regular treasury and shall
thereafter be considered moneys appropriated for the use of the Commission as
hereinafter set forth. The Commission shall, during each fiscal year, and not
later than July 31 submit to the Town Council a request for an appropriation of
money to be expended by the Commission in addition to any gifts received by it;
which request shall show specifically the maximum amount requested and the
purposes for which such moneys are to be expended, as well as the specified
amount to be spent for each purpose. Such request shall be in writing and
signed by the Chairperson of the Commission. In addition to the requests
submitted during the month of July of each fiscal year, the Commission may
during the remainder of the fiscal year make additional requests for an
appropriation in the same manner and form as herein provided. Upon the receipt
of any such request the Town Council may consider and act upon the same at any
regular meeting of the Town Council granting such request in whole or in part
or wholly refusing such request as the Town Council may deem proper.
      (3)   The Commission shall not expend any money and shall not enter into
any contract directly or indirectly involving any expenditure of money unless
or until the funds for such expenditure have been specifically appropriated by
the Town Council in the manner hereinbefore set forth; and any expenditure of
such funds, or contract directly or indirectly involving the expenditure of
such funds, without such specific appropriation therefore, shall be null and
void; and any moneys paid out without the full authorization under the terms of
this chapter shall be recoverable for an on behalf of the town either against
the person or persons receiving the same or against the members of the
Commission making such unlawful expenditures.
   (D)   Powers and duties with respect to planning.
      (1)   It shall be the function and duty of the Commission to make and
adopt a master plan under and by virtue of the provisions of the W. Va. Code §§
8-5-1 et seq., as is necessary to protect the community against inadequate
streets, highways, sewers and inadequately planned territory. Such plans shall
show recommendations for new streets, bridges, parks, parkways, playgrounds or
any other public areas or public improvements. Such plans with the accompanying
maps, charts and descriptive matter shall show the Commission’s recommendations
for the development of said territory including among other things the general
location, character and the extent of all streets, bridges, squares,
playgrounds, parks, terminals and other public buildings and other public
property and the general location and extent of public utilities and terminals
whether publicly or privately operated, for water, light, sanitation,
transportation, communication, power and other purposes; also the removal,
reuse or extension of any of the foregoing streets, alleyways, grounds, open
spaces, property, utilities or terminals. As the work of the making of the
master plan progresses, the Commission may from time to time recommend the
adoption and publishing of the part or parts of the master adjacent thereto.
The Commission may from time to time add to, amend or extend the plan.
      (2)   All plans, plats or re-plats of land, land out in building lots,
and the streets intended to be dedicated to public use, shall be submitted by
the owner or promoter of any such subdivision or re-subdivisions to said
Commission; and before any lots are sold therefrom and before any such plat or
plan shall be filed in the office of the County Clerk of the County Court, as
provided by law, it shall first be submitted to the Commission for their
considerations and recommendation, and shall first be adopted
and approved by the Town Council.
      (3)   The Clerk of the County Court is hereby notified not to file any
such plat or re-plat in his or her office until such plat or re-plat shall have
indorsed upon it the fact it has first been submitted to the Commission, to the
Mayor and Town Council, and by the Mayor and Town Council duly approved.
   (E)   Power and duties with respect to zoning. It shall also be the function
and duty of the Commission to make and adopt a master plan for the physical
development of the town with respect to zoning. Zoning work of the Commission
shall be handled on a block basis, covering as a unit one or more existing
blocks. The Commission may have public hearings as to each area prior to its
recommendations for adoption of zoning in that section. Public notice of such
hearing shall be given by the Commission, which said notice shall be published
in a newspaper published in said town or in the event that no newspaper is
published in said town, the notice of that public hearing shall be by written
notice posted in at least ten public places throughout said town, with at least
two of said public notices to be placed at the area proposed to be affected by
said zoning. The Commission shall also prepare a zoning ordinance, along with
their recommendations, to Town Council from time to time. The Commission or any
interested party may request the presence of Town Council at any such public
hearing.
(Ord. passed 2-10-2000)
§ 153.11 ADJUSTMENTS AND APPEALS.
   (A)   The Planning and Zoning Commission, subject to the approval and
confirmation of the Town Council, in each case as hereinafter provided shall
have power to grant adjustments and exceptions in and to any of the provisions
of this chapter to the extent of the following and no further:
      (1)   To vary or modify the strict application of any of the regulations
or provisions contained in this chapter in cases in which there are practical
difficulties or unnecessary hardships in the way of such strict application;
and
      (2)   To permit the extension of a district where the boundary line
thereof divides a lot in one ownership at the time of the passage of this
chapter.
   (B)   Application for any adjustment permissible under the provisions of
this section shall be made to the Town Recorder in the form of a written
application for a building permit or for a permit to use the property or
premises as set forth in said application. Upon receipt of any such
application, such officer shall set a time and place for a public hearing
before the Planning and Zoning Commission on such application. Such officer
shall cause public notice of such public hearing to be given by causing one
notice thereof to be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the
town at least ten days before the date of such hearing. At said hearing the
applicant shall present a statement and adequate evidence in such form as the
Planning and Zoning Commission may require, showing the following:
      (1)   There are special circumstances or conditions affecting land,
building or use referred to in the application;
      (2)   The granting of the application is necessary for the preservation
and enjoyment of substantial property rights; and
      (3)   The granting of such application will not materially affect
adversely the health or safety of persons residing or working in the
neighborhood of the property of the applicant and will not materially be
detrimental to the public welfare of injurious to property or improvements in
said neighborhood.
   (C)   The Planning and Zoning Commission will thereupon make its decision
upon the said application. The Planning and Zoning Commission shall report its
recommendations, either to deny or grant the application, to tire Town Council
within 14 days after the filing of the application.
   (D)   In recommending any adjustment or variance under the provisions of
this section, the Planning and Zoning Commission shall designate such
conditions in connection therewith as will in its opinion, secure substantially
the objectives of the regulations or provisions to which such adjustment or
variance is granted, as to light, air and the public health, safety, comfort,
convenience and general welfare. No permit shall be issued under the provisions
of this section unless and until a decision of the Planning and Zoning
Commission, as aforesaid, approving the same is approved and confirmed by the
Town Council, with respect thereto and all facts in connection therewith, and
shall specifically and fully set forth any adjustment or variance granted and
the conditions designated. Upon receipt of such report the Town Council either
shall by resolution approve and confirm said decision, with or without changes,
whereupon the permit as applied for may be issued; or shall refuse to approve
and confirm such decision. In all cases in which adjustments or variances are
granted under the provisions of this section the Planning and Zoning Commission
and the Town Council shall require such evidence and guarantees as it may deem
to be necessary that the conditions designated in the connection therewith are
being and will be complied with.
(Ord. passed 2-10-2000; Ord. passed 6-14-2018)
§ 153.12 SPECIAL USE PERMIT.
   (A)   Special use permits may be issued for any of the following:
      (1)   Any of the uses or purposes for which such permits are required or
permitted by the provisions of this chapter;
      (2)   Public utility or public service uses or public building in any
district when found to be necessary for the public health, safety, convenience
or welfare;
      (3)   Commercial excavating of natural materials used for building or
construction purposes, in any district;
      (4)   To classify as a conforming use any institutional use existing in
any district at the time of the establishment of such district; and
      (5)   To permit the location of any uses in a district from which they
are excluded by the provisions of this chapter.
   (B)   (1)   Application for the issuance of a special use permit shall be
made to the Planning and Zoning Commission; provided, that any proceedings to
classify certain uses as conforming uses as provided in this section may be
initiated either by such application or by the Town Council or by the Planning
and Zoning Commission. The Planning and Zoning Commission may hold such
hearings on the proposal to issue a special use permit as it may consider
necessary; but at least one public hearing shall be held on any application for
a use permit for the establishment of any use listed in division (A) of this
section.
      (2)   Following the aforesaid hearing, the Planning and Zoning Commission
shall make a report to the Town Council whatever action it deems advisable; but
it shall not recommend the granting of a permit unless it finds that the
establishment, maintenance or conducting of the use for which a use permit is
sought will not under the circumstances of the particular case be detrimental
to the health, safety, morals, comfort, convenience or welfare of the persons
residing or working in the neighborhood of such use, nor be detrimental to the
public welfare, nor be injurious to property or improvements in the
neighborhood.
      (3)   It may designate conditions and require guarantees in the granting
of use permits in the manner provided in §
153.11 for the granting of adjustments. Upon receipt of the report of the
Planning and Zoning Commission, the Town Council shall hold whatever public
hearings it deems advisable and shall make a decision upon the proposal to
grant a use permit.
      (4)   If it finds that the conditions exist which are necessary under
this section before the Planning and Zoning Commission may recommend the
granting of a use permit, the Town Council may grant the use permit and it may
attach to the permit such conditions and guarantees as are provided for in §
153.11 for the granting of adjustments.
   (C)   Any use permitted under the terms of any special use permit shall be
established and conducted in conformity to the terms of such permit and of any
conditions designated in connection therewith.
(Ord. passed 2-10-2000; Ord. passed 6-14-2018)
§ 153.13 AMENDMENT.
   This chapter may be amended whenever the public necessity and convenience
and the general welfare require such amendment by following the procedure
specified in this section.
   (A)   An amendment may be initiated by the Town Council or the Planning and
Zoning Commission, or by the verified petition of not less than 50% of those
property owners within 300 feet of the proposed change.
   (B)   (1)   Before any amendment is adopted, the Planning and Zoning
Commission shall hold at least one public hearing thereon after ten days
published notice of the time and place of such hearing. Following such hearing
the Planning and Zoning Commission shall make a report of its findings and
recommendations with respect to the proposed amendment and shall file a copy
with the Town Recorder within ten days of the meeting at which the date of the
hearing was set.
      (2)   Failure of the Planning and Zoning Commission to report within ten
days shall be deemed to be approval by the Planning and Zoning Commission of
the proposed amendment.
   (C)   Upon the filing of such report or upon the expiration of such ten days
as aforesaid, the Town Council shall hold such public hearings upon the
amendment as it deems advisable. After the conclusion of such hearings, if any,
the Town Council may adopt the amendment or any part thereof in such form as it
deems advisable. Such amendment shall be effective only if two-thirds of all
the members of the Town Council concur in its passage.
(Ord. passed 2-10-2000)
§ 153.14 ENFORCEMENT.
   It shall be the duty of the town building inspector or other duly authorized
agent of the Town Council to enforce this chapter through the proper legal
channels.
(Ord. passed 2-10-2000)
§ 153.99 PENALTY.
   Any person who shall violate or fail to comply with any of the provisions of
this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall
be punished by a fine not to exceed $500 or by imprisonment not to exceed 60
days for each offense. Each day that the violation is permitted to exist shall
constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. passed 2-10-2000)
